		<title>vote</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/shut-up-and-vote/vote/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Nov 2012 23:31:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"About Us Title","type":"title","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"center","icon":"","title":"About Write On Target","caption":"","right-text":"Read More","right-text-link":"","margin-bottom":"40px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"About WOT","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p>Write On Target was formed in 1993 after Elizabeth Borton, then a 24-year veteran of the communications industry, ventured into the HR communications arena and said, “Boy, these folks could use some help!” She decided to use her expertise at simplifying the complex to educate employees and retirees across the country.</p><p>Today, Write On Target, Inc. is a full-service HR & Employee communications company that brings together the best of both worlds… professionals with in-depth knowledge and experience in HR combined with a creative staff with impressive marketing skills. Our clients include Fortune 500 companies whose audiences vary as much by demographics and culture as they do media of choice.</p><p>Write On Target’s business model is unique in that we do not believe that “bigger is better.” We purposely limit our client list so we can provide responsive, nimble service. Each client works directly with a writer/consultant who stays on the account year-round, not just for a specific project. Additional in-house talent, such as design and production, are pulled on to projects as needed.</p><p>At Write On Target, every team member is familiar with, and able to respond to, the needs of our clients quickly and efficiently.</p><p>We find this unique level of intimacy and consistency enables us to deliver superior service and results-proven materials that impact employees, as well as organizations as a whole.</p><p> </p>","margin-bottom":"60px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Title","type":"title","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"center","icon":"","title":"Our Philosophy","caption":"","right-text":"Read More","right-text-link":"","margin-bottom":"40px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Philosophy","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<ul><li><strong>We are passionate about employees’ rights to understand</strong> the total rewards of working for their employer: from benefits and compensation to career development opportunities and retirement planning.</li><li><strong>We believe copy and design go hand in hand.</strong> Messages should be clear and concise. Designs should be eye-catching and easy to scan, allowing the reader to quickly absorb key points.</li><li><strong>We work as a seamless extension of our clients’ staffs…</strong> a reliable resource that will take the initiative to see projects through from start to finish.</li><li><strong>We believe in doing things right the first time.</strong> Exceptional quality and service each and every time that is on target.</li></ul>","margin-bottom":"60px"}}]]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>content-with-sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"About Us Title","type":"title","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"center","icon":"","title":"About Write On Target","caption":"","right-text":"Read More","right-text-link":"","margin-bottom":"40px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"About WOT","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p>Write On Target was formed in 1993 after Elizabeth Borton, then a 24-year veteran of the communications industry, ventured into the HR communications arena and said, “Boy, these folks could use some help!” She decided to use her expertise at simplifying the complex to educate employees and retirees across the country.</p><p>Today, Write On Target, Inc. is a full-service HR & Employee communications company that brings together the best of both worlds… professionals with in-depth knowledge and experience in HR combined with a creative staff with impressive marketing skills. Our clients include Fortune 500 companies whose audiences vary as much by demographics and culture as they do media of choice.</p><p>Write On Target’s business model is unique in that we do not believe that “bigger is better.” We purposely limit our client list so we can provide responsive, nimble service. Each client works directly with a writer/consultant who stays on the account year-round, not just for a specific project. Additional in-house talent, such as design and production, are pulled on to projects as needed.</p><p>At Write On Target, every team member is familiar with, and able to respond to, the needs of our clients quickly and efficiently.</p><p>We find this unique level of intimacy and consistency enables us to deliver superior service and results-proven materials that impact employees, as well as organizations as a whole.</p><p> </p>","margin-bottom":"60px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Title","type":"title","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"center","icon":"","title":"Our Philosophy","caption":"","right-text":"Read More","right-text-link":"","margin-bottom":"40px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Philosophy","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<ul><li><strong>We are passionate about employees’ rights to understand</strong> the total rewards of working for their employer: from benefits and compensation to career development opportunities and retirement planning.</li><li><strong>We believe copy and design go hand in hand.</strong> Messages should be clear and concise. Designs should be eye-catching and easy to scan, allowing the reader to quickly absorb key points.</li><li><strong>We work as a seamless extension of our clients’ staffs…</strong> a reliable resource that will take the initiative to see projects through from start to finish.</li><li><strong>We believe in doing things right the first time.</strong> Exceptional quality and service each and every time that is on target.</li></ul>","margin-bottom":"60px"}}]]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How We Make It Simple</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/about-us/how_we_make_it_simple/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Mar 2015 00:51:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bbotos]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://dev.writetarget.com/?page_id=2549</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2549</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-03-23 00:51:23</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-03-23 00:51:23</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>how_we_make_it_simple</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1122</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>2</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>

			<wp:meta_key>post-option</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[{"sidebar":"no-sidebar","left-sidebar":"Footer 1","right-sidebar":"Footer 1","page-style":"normal","navigation-area":"top","show-title":"disable","page-caption":"","show-content":"enable","header-background":""}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>above-sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Background/Parallax Wrapper","type":"parallax-bg-wrapper","items":[],"option":{"page-item-id":"","type":"image","background":"3213","background-speed":"0","pattern":"1","video":"","video-overlay":"0.5","video-player":"enable","skin":"no-skin","border":"none","border-top-color":"#e9e9e9","border-bottom-color":"#e9e9e9","padding-top":"350px","padding-bottom":"348px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Title","type":"title","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"center","icon":"","title":"How We Make It Simple","caption":"","right-text":"Read More","right-text-link":"","margin-bottom":"40px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p>Let’s face it, benefits are complicated. That’s why you need the communication experts at Write On Target. We make it easy for you by handling every detail—from concept to completion—and every step in between. Our team will get up to speed fast and deliver results quickly. No hassles. No worries.</p><p>It’s our passion to translate “benefit geek” language into clear, concise communications. From enrollment packages to SPDs to interactive Web sites. We’ll simplify your benefits communications for both your employees and HR staff and we’ll do it on time, on budget and on target.</p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}]]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>content-with-sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-2","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5 style=|gq2|text-align: center;|gq2|><strong>We Make it Simple for Your Employees</strong></h5><p>When employees receive any piece of benefits or HR communication, they only want to know three things:</p><ol><li>What’s this about?</li><li>How does it impact me?</li><li>What do I have to do?</li></ol><p>That’s why we use a unique pyramid approach to structure our communications from “need to know,” to “nice to know,” then “benefit geek” (required legal language). Material is presented so it’s easy to scan and absorb, clearly identifying key points.</p><p> </p><h5>The Result?</h5><p>Fewer questions. More participation. And a greater appreciation for the value of your total rewards package.</p><p> </p><p><a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Pyramid-RGB.png|gq2|><img class=|gq2|alignnone wp-image-2960 size-full|gq2| src=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Pyramid-RGB.png|gq2| alt=|gq2|Pyramid (RGB)|gq2| width=|gq2|1435|gq2| height=|gq2|969|gq2| /></a></p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"1/2"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-2","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5 style=|gq2|text-align: center;|gq2|><strong>We Make it Simple for Your HR Staff</strong></h5><p>You’ll find that our in-depth knowledge and expertise will make us a valuable part of your HR team...one you can rely upon to get things done. Here’s why:</p><ul><li><strong>A valuable extension of your team</strong>: With Write On Target, you work directly with the person who writes your copy. No middle man (or woman) to cause confusion. Plus, your writer/consultant is on your account year-round, not just for a specific project. Consistent, professional assistance backed by an in-house team of communication experts...it’s the cost-effective way to expand your team without the overhead.</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Left- and right-brained</strong>: We bring the best of both worlds...technical understanding of HR issues combined with award-winning marketing skills. Our unique, creative approach stands out in today’s multi-media world to grab attention and quickly communicate your message.</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Strategic thinkers</strong>: We don’t just look at a single project, we look at the big picture. What are your objectives? What is the current mindset of your employees? What is the most effective way to deliver your message? And most importantly, how can this project support the success of your overall objectives?</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Hand-holding not required</strong>: HR benefits and employee communications are the only things we do, so it doesn’t take long to get us up to speed. We’ll take the initiative to get your projects done on time, on target and on budget with minimum disruption to your staff.</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Team players</strong>: We regularly work directly with our clients’ vendors to gather information or mail data needed for a project. We also work closely with corporate communications to ensure materials meet company standards and reinforce core values.</li></ul><ul><li><strong>Honest and forthright</strong>: We’re not just another vendor trying to make a buck...we get more satisfaction in seeing you get results! So if you want a big campaign but experience has shown that a simple postcard will do the trick, we’ll let you know. It’s simple...we want you to succeed.</li></ul><p> </p><h5>The Result?</h5><p>On-target employee communications. Less stress on your team. Measurable results you can deliver to management.</p>","margin-bottom":"80px"}}],"option":{},"size":"1/2"}]]]></wp:meta_value>

We’ll help you promote the event and welcome recipients, then deliver a high-impact presentation that |gq2|wows.|gq2| We'll even stay afterwards so attendees can ask additional questions or talk one-on-one with our speakers.</p><p>Whatever support you need, we’ll deliver. Contact us to discuss your upcoming event. We want to help you make it a big success!</p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}]]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>content-with-sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column3-5","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5>Hot Topics</h5><p>With 21 years of experience in benefits and HR communications, the experts at Write On Target are well versed in the strategies, tactics and tools it takes to break through today’s clutter to engage and motivate employees. Our unique, entertaining presentation style will provide attendees with practical tips they can immediately apply, as well as real-life case studies that put theory into action to produce measurable results.</p><p> </p><p><strong style=|gq2|line-height: 1.5;|gq2|>Monday Morning Quarterback — How to Analyze Your 2015 Annual Enrollment and Prepare for Next Year</strong></p><p>The stress of annual enrollment is over. You put in a ton of work and now you can look forward to the coming year. But not so fast. Just like any winning team, it’s important to reflect on how your organization performed. What were the winning touchdowns? Any interceptions that you wish you could have avoided? If you added up the penalties, would you still consider it a win?</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Identify key metrics and feedback tools to measure success.</li><li>Use tools to streamline next year's planning process.</li><li>Use marketing and education techniques to keep the momentum going.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><strong> Using Data to Target Communications and Drive Participant Behavior</strong></p><p>Data segmentation can be extremely complex. Big data tools and resources are used to analyze multiple cross sections of data to create specific user profiles. Communication messages are then segmented and customized to meet the preferences of each profile.</p><p>Don’t let big data discourage you. There are simpler ways to use the data you currently have at your fingertips to target your communications and achieve measurable results.</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Use HR data to target communications.</li><li>Segment messages to increase engagement.</li><li>Maximize communication budgets to get the best results.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Why Storytelling Should Be a Key HR Competency</strong></p><p>A well-told story can make us laugh, cry, feel anger or joy. It’s like opening a window into the minds of the listeners. Storytelling can be used to increase engagement, encourage action and enhance an organization.</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Implement storytelling techniques to attract, retain and train employees.</li><li>Share employees’ stories to pique emotion, stimulate a need, elicit a vision and increase engagement.</li><li>Encourage storytelling to uncover common challenges among your HR team and develop solutions.</li><li>Use storytelling techniques to communicate a clear vision of the role HR plays in the success of the organization.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><strong>5 Common Communication Blunders </strong><strong>(and How to Avoid Them)</strong></p><p>To become a true business partner, HR professionals need to know how to maximize every portion of their budget to get the best return on investment. Sadly, although organizations invest a great deal of time and money designing competitive benefit programs, they sometimes drop the ball when it comes to communicating those benefits.</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Engage spouses/partners when communicating benefits.</li><li>Involve organization leaders as a sounding board.</li><li>Communicate in an honest, forthright manner to build trust.</li><li>Focus on key messages in initial communications, then direct participants to sources, such as websites, for more detail.</li><li>Keep messages clear, concise and consistent.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Benefits Communications Made Simple (3 Techniques and 3 Case Studies Prove You Can Cut Through Clutter to Get Results)</strong></p><p>Benefits aren’t exactly simple. They're complicated, confusing and (thanks to the government) constantly changing. But there are three simple techniques you can start using immediately to cut through the noise of today’s multi-media environment, grab your employees’ attention and motivate them to take action. Translate theory into practical application by reviewing three real-world case studies that produced measurable results.</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Create communications that speak directly to the target audience to engage them on a personal level.</li><li>Focus communications so key messages break through the clutter.</li><li>Streamline communications to eliminate the “fire hose effect” on your target audience.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><strong>Convert your SPDs from “Seriously Painful Documents” to Easy-to-Read-and-Use Summary Plan Descriptions</strong></p><p>The government requires employers to provide Summary Plan Descriptions (SPDs) to participants eligible for an ERISA-covered health or retirement plan. Here's the problem: Participants want an SPD that’s understandable. Lawyers want an SPD that provides protection. The benefits department wants an SPD that answers questions. So how can you meet all these criteria and still produce a useable document?</p><p>In this presentation, participants will learn how to:</p><ul><li>Write an SPD so it is easy to understand and use.</li><li>Format text to increase scanability and readability.</li><li>Record, maintain and distribute SPDs economically, either electronically or in print.</li></ul><p><em>This program has been approved for 1 (HR General) recertification credit hour toward PHR, SPHR, and GPHR recertification through the HR Certification Institute. </em></p><p> </p><p><a href=|gq2|http://writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/HR-Certification-Institute-APPROVED-Seal.jpg|gq2|><img class=|gq2|alignnone size-medium wp-image-3228|gq2| src=|gq2|http://writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/HR-Certification-Institute-APPROVED-Seal-300x300.jpg|gq2| alt=|gq2|HR Certification Institute APPROVED Seal|gq2| width=|gq2|300|gq2| height=|gq2|300|gq2| /></a></p><p><em>The use of this seal is not an endorsement by the HR Certification Institute of the quality of the program. It means that this program has met the HR Certification Institute's criteria to be pre-approved for recertification credit.</em></p><p> </p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"3/5"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column2-5","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5>Available Speakers</h5><p>Each of our dynamic speakers have been integrally involved in creating benefits and HR communications for over a decade. Each has experience speaking at national, regional and local events with an average rating of 9.0 out of 10!</p><p><strong><a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/speaker-bios/|gq2|>Elizabeth Borton</a> - </strong>President and Founder<br /> <a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/speaker-bios/|gq2|><strong>Jennifer Weatherly</strong></a> - Vice President Client Services and Senior Consultant<br /> <a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/speaker-bios/|gq2|><strong>Kelly O’Connor</strong></a> - Senior Level Account Lead and Writer</p><p> </p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Column Service","type":"column-service","option":{"page-item-id":"","icon":"","title":"What others are saying","style":"type-1","content":"<p><em>Good practical approach.</em><br /><em>Engaging presentation.</em><br /><em>Very creative program! Thank you for sharing!</em><br /><em>Eye opening. Excellent!</em><br /><em>One of the best sessions!</em><br /><strong>ISCEBS national conference feedback</strong></p><p><em>“VERY good! Bring her back!</em><br /><em>I really like the way she kept the audience engaged.<br />I received good tips for SPDs and future plans. She was very good and knew her information. Very creative. Very useful and practical information that can be easily applied.”</em><br /><strong>Ohio SHRM feedback</strong></p><p><em>I really enjoyed the case studies where participants not only provided creative, </em><br /><em>real-world examples, but also provided success metrics. The best value is the ability to prove these programs work.</em> <br /><strong>Greater Cincinnati Compensation and Benefit Association</strong></p><p><em>Writing professionally or at least intelligently is so important because oftentimes people base their first impression of you on how well you write. This session was so relevant for work or personal communication. Loved it!</em> <br /><strong>HR executive</strong></p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}},{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<ul><li><h5><a href=|gq2|http://writetarget.com/speaker-bios/|gq2|>Meet our Speakers</a></h5></li><li><h5><a href=|gq2|http://writetarget.com/contact-page/|gq2|>Contact our Speakers</a></h5></li></ul><p> </p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"2/5"}]]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>content-with-sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[[{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-5","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p><a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Elizabeth_bw_01-e1428351165543.jpg|gq2|><img class=|gq2| size-medium wp-image-2901 alignleft|gq2| src=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Elizabeth_bw_01-199x300.jpg|gq2| alt=|gq2|Elizabeth_bw_01|gq2| width=|gq2|199|gq2| height=|gq2|300|gq2| /></a></p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"1/4"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-3","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5>Elizabeth Borton, President and Founder, Write On Target, Inc.</h5><p>Elizabeth Borton was a 24-year veteran of the communications/marketing industry before entering the HR communications arena. She immediately put her skills to work, translating “benefit geek” into clear, concise communications. She formed Write On Target in 1993, focusing the business solely on meeting the unique communication needs of the HR community.</p><p>Today, her team works closely with large employers who are frustrated that their employees do not understand their benefits or HR programs, but have limited resources and time to get the job done right. The effectiveness of the unique Write On Target communications approach is proven by the measurable results her team consistently delivers to each of their long-term clients.</p><p>Elizabeth has a Bachelor’s of Arts in Communications from the University of Dayton and is a member of IFEBP, SHRM, the Greater Cincinnati HR Association and the Greater Cincinnati Compensation and Benefits Association. Her company is a Certified Women Business Enterprise that serves clients throughout the country. She and her team have shared their expertise at numerous national conferences including the International Society of Employee Benefit Specialists (ISCEBS) symposium as well as regional, state and local SHRM and CEBs conferences. To sum it up, Elizabeth says her mission in life is to make benefits simple and easy to understand.</p>","margin-bottom":"80px"}}],"option":{},"size":"3/4"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-4","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p><a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Jennifer_bw_01-e1428351154510.jpg|gq2|><img class=|gq2| size-medium wp-image-2902 alignleft|gq2| src=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Jennifer_bw_01-199x300.jpg|gq2| alt=|gq2|Jennifer_bw_01|gq2| width=|gq2|199|gq2| height=|gq2|300|gq2| /></a></p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"1/4"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-1","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5>Jennifer Weatherly, Vice President Client Services and Senior Consultant</h5><p>Jennifer has 21 years of marketing and communications experience, eleven in HR and benefits communications. As Vice President of Client Services and Senior Consultant, she is responsible for overseeing the planning and execution of high impact communication strategies for all of Write On Target Inc.’s large-employer clients.</p><p>Her background includes holding various positions within major companies including Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Infotel Distributing, Pam Mar Color Service, Systematic Design and WKSW radio. This diverse experience provides Jennifer with a unique practical understanding of the entire spectrum of communicating employee benefits from message to distribution.</p><p>Jennifer is a graduate of Ohio University with a B.S. in Journalism (Advertising Management). She is a board member of the Cincinnati International Association of Business Communicators and won the 2007 Bronze Quill Award of Excellence for Programs and Campaigns. Jennifer has spoken at International Society of Certified Employee Benefit Specialists (ISCEBS) symposiums and conducted webinars on writing effective communications documents.</p>","margin-bottom":"80px"}}],"option":{},"size":"3/4"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-4","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<p><a href=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Kelly_bw_01-e1428351125716.jpg|gq2|><img class=|gq2| size-medium wp-image-2904 alignleft|gq2| src=|gq2|http://dev.writetarget.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Kelly_bw_01-199x300.jpg|gq2| alt=|gq2|Kelly_bw_01|gq2| width=|gq2|199|gq2| height=|gq2|300|gq2| /></a></p>","margin-bottom":"20px"}}],"option":{},"size":"1/4"},{"item-type":"wrapper","item-builder-title":"Column Item","type":"column1-1","items":[{"item-type":"item","item-builder-title":"Content","type":"content","option":{"page-item-id":"","title-type":"none","icon":"","title":"","caption":"","content":"<h5>Kelly O'Connor, PHR, GBA, Senior Level Account Lead and Writer</h5><p>Kelly is a senior level account lead and writer at Write On Target, Inc. For over 10 years, she has assisted large employer clients (3,000+ employees) in the development of communication strategies, plans and budgets. She then works with her clients throughout the year to create and distribute a variety of communication campaigns involving health and welfare, wellness, and retirement plans. As a result, she has helped her clients to deliver quality HR and benefits programs while increasing employee engagement and participation.</p><p>Kelly’s background includes holding various positions in HR departments at Ford Motor Company, MetLife and Erickson Retirement Communities. She graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in Human Resource Management from Central Michigan University. She has spoken at the national conference for the 401(k) Profit Sharing Council of America and is very active on a local and state level of the Society of Human Resource Management (SHRM). In fact, she is currently the President of the Miami Valley HR Association.</p>","margin-bottom":"80px"}}],"option":{},"size":"3/4"}]]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Get &#039;Em Outta Their Chairs</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/get-em-outta-their-chairs/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Jan 2012 18:33:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=92</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For the WOT 2012 wellness initiative, we invested in a new high-tech toy – the Fitbit. It’s a pedometer on steroids. It counts our steps taken, stairs climbed, calories burned, and even watches our sleep pattern! Then it syncs up with our computers so we can track our progress online.

After one week:
<ul>
	<li>Elizabeth and Becky are going gangbusters racking up steps.</li>
	<li>Kelly is surprised at how little she moves during work hours and thinking about what she can do while chained to her desk.</li>
	<li>Jennifer and Julie… well they’re still having trouble opening the package.</li>
</ul>
Is this response similar to what your company’s experienced? Aside from providing scissors with each package, <strong>what can you do to motivate your employees?</strong>

<strong>Remind. Remind. Remind.</strong> Unlike New Year’s resolutions, your wellness program is not short-lived. You’re going for the long haul here with employees. Invest in communicating continuously and often. In today’s fast-paced, mobile environment, <strong>it takes about seven mentions for your message to be heard.</strong> Even more than that to make it stick. Stay in front of your employees, even those who have engaged and adopted healthy lifestyles. People slip. <em>Becky forgot to wear her Fitbit today. But, she did remember she forgot it. That’s a plus.</em>

<strong>Make your communications simple, relatable and emotional.</strong> If the communications are too cumbersome, employees will assume the wellness program is difficult as well.
<ul>
	<li>Keep it short and sweet.</li>
	<li>Talk <em>with</em> employees, not <em>at</em> them. Remind them of why they should care to get healthy. Not why the company thinks they should get healthy.</li>
	<li>Be emotional with your word usage and imagery. It’s OK to hit a nerve – that sparks action.</li>
	<li>If your program’s been around awhile, use testimonials to show that others are having success. Nothing spurs action like competition. <em>If Kelly can get 7,500 steps, by golly, Jennifer can get 15,000! That is, once she opens the package.</em></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Are You Missing the Boat?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/are-you-missing-the-boat/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Jan 2012 16:40:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=98</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We came across a wellness mailer the other day that spurred some discussion because there were a few places in the text where the employer missed out on an opportunity to educate and engage their employees.

<strong>Don’t get your employees in the boat and then not steer them in the right direction. </strong>

An important thing to remember in all communications: If you don’t fill in the blanks for your audience, the audience will do it for you, and what they think will most likely <em>not </em>match your intent.

<strong>Examples of what we’re talking about…</strong>

<em>Sample 1 from the mailer:
</em>“As of September 30, 2011, ABC Company medical and prescription drug claims equaled $75 million; of that, employees paid $12 million in co-pays and co-insurance.”

Left on their own to understand the intent of this statement, how do you think ABC Company’s employees responded? In most cases, they’re probably going to say, <em>“See, we pay $12 million. We pay a lot for health care.”</em> Or, worse (for those of you who are self-insured), <em>“So, the insurance company with their big bucks pays the rest.” </em>

<strong><em>When writing, ask, “What is my point for telling the audience this information?” Then clearly answer that question in your text.  </em></strong>

<em>Sample 1 rewrite: (for self-insured companies)
</em>“As of September 30, 2011, ABC Company’s medical and prescription drug claims equaled $75 million. Of that, employees covered $12 million. <strong>Who pays the other $63 million?</strong> ABC Company does. That’s why taking care of your health is so important. The more we pay for high medical and prescription bills, the less we have to pay toward other employee benefits – like merit increases, bonuses, profit sharing, etc. 

<em>Sample 2 from the mailer:
</em>“<strong>Take Advantage of Your Benefits: </strong>Remember,<strong> </strong>ABC Company covers preventive care 100%. Last year, 41% of our participants went through preventive care treatment.”<strong></strong>

What does ABC Company want them to know here? Is 41% a lot, or a little? And who even cares how many went through? And who the heck is a participant?

<em>Sample 2 rewrite:
</em>“<strong>Take Advantage of Your Benefits: </strong>Don’t forget! ABC Company pays for annual physicals and preventive care check-ups 100%. But <strong>less than half of our employees</strong> are visiting their doctor annually. <strong>Have you had your check-up yet?</strong> It’s important that you do. That’s why we pay for it.” <strong></strong>

These are just a few examples of an employer communicating from <em>their</em> point of view rather than from the employees’. Take a look at some of your communications. Are you missing the boat?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>are-you-missing-the-boat</wp:post_name>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Perception on Precipitation</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/perception-on-precipitation/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 Jan 2012 16:02:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=105</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s snowing in the cornfields of Ohio, which, in our office, has created a lesson in perceptions…
<ul>
	<li>Kelly is in complete bliss — expounding on how magical the snow is and how we have our very own snow globe. (She’s from Michigan.)</li>
	<li>Becky is already in white knuckles mode. (Snow is not her friend.)</li>
	<li>Julie is grousing about how she hopes it stops soon as to not conflict with her speed-demon ability to run three teenagers around all night.</li>
	<li>Elizabeth is outright not happy — as she makes her trek back from Indianapolis.</li>
	<li>Jennifer, well, we don’t even know if she’s noticed that it’s snowing.   </li>
</ul>
<strong>One event causing a variety of reactions… </strong>all based on our individual perceptions of the same situation.<strong> </strong>

When you send out a communication, do you know how your message will be perceived? As communicators, we must step outside of what we know and try to look at it from each employee’s perspective.

The next time you create a communication, we challenge you to step back and ask “how would I perceive this if I was in the reader’s shoes?”]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Living On a Boat &amp; HR Communications?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/living-on-a-boat-hr-communications/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jan 2012 18:44:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=112</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

You might ask yourself, “What does living on a boat have to do with HR communications?” Well, I gave a speech on just that topic last week at a joint meeting of the Indiana Compensation &amp; Benefits Professionals and the Indy SHRM. (Great group of folks! Really enjoyed it.)

As I prepared, I looked back at the blog I wrote while my husband and I cruised on our 42’ sailboat for nine months (<a href="http://www.billandboop.blogspot.com">billandboop.blogspot.com</a>). The blog brought back a lot of great memories and reminded me of many lessons I learned along the way that absolutely apply to HR communications. The most important lesson was simply this: <strong>“less is more.”</strong>

You see, when you live on a boat you have to prioritize and limit what you bring aboard. You have no car, so you can only buy the amount of groceries that fit into a backpack or on the handlebars of your bike. Your wardrobe (if you can call it that) is limited to what can fit in one drawer and a two-foot closet. You get the picture.

The same is true with your HR communications. Less is more. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve seen folks try to stuff everything about a subject into a simple brochure. The result? Employees get confused and overwhelmed and toss it aside. Then HR wonders why “no one reads anything we send out.”

Hey, I’ve been a writer all my life. I would love to think that everyone hangs on my every word, but they don’t. Keep in mind that whenever employees see something from your HR group, they only want to know three things:
<ol>
	<li>What’s this about?</li>
	<li>How’s it impact me?</li>
	<li>What do I need to do, by when?</li>
</ol>
So the next time you’re putting together a communication, think like a cruiser: prioritize your messages and limit the content. It will help your employees to navigate through the information much quicker to answer those three burning questions.

Wishing you smooth sailing in the coming year!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Onboarding... What about Keepboarding?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/onboarding-what-about-keepboarding/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Jan 2012 16:51:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=135</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After the rush of Annual Enrollment, next on our “to do’s” is updating new hire and onboarding materials. This got us thinking about the idea of “keepboarding”... trying to keep the employees you have by reminding them of why they came to work for the company in the first place. You invest such time and energy in talking to new hires. When do you retell the story to veteran employees?

<strong><em>Help employees retain what you told them day one, so you help the company retain the employee long term. </em></strong>

<strong><em> </em></strong><strong><em>Two ideas… </em></strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>90-day check-up:</strong> The typical probationary period has ended; the manager is reviewing performance and revisiting expectations. What if this time was also used to see if the new employee has any questions about how his benefits or other HR programs work? Understanding leads to appreciation.</li>
	<li><strong>Re-orientation: </strong>Once a year, every year, hold a Company-wide (or location-wide/plant-wide) meeting to re-orient employees with your benefits and HR programs. Just use a skinny-down version of the onboarding presentation. Plus, take the opportunity to spotlight some of the under-used programs and address common questions or misunderstandings.</li>
</ul>
We understand we may be over-simplifying the idea of employee retention. A lot more goes into it than just benefits. But it may be an overlooked piece at your company. Keepboarding is something you can start doing today.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Top Four Challenges HR is Facing in 2012…and How Communications Can Help</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/top-four-challenges-hr-is-facing-in-2012and-how-communications-can-help/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Feb 2012 17:25:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetarget.wordpress.com/?p=140</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the past year, we’ve attended many HR functions and conferences. Even spoke at a few of them. And we noticed some recurring themes as to the challenges that HR folks are facing, namely:
<ol>
	<li>Dealing with multiple generations in the workplace;</li>
	<li>Retaining talent;</li>
	<li>Becoming less tactical and more strategic and;</li>
	<li>Adapting to new technologies.</li>
</ol>
Since we’re all about supporting HR professionals to be as successful as possible, we put on our thinking caps and developed some ideas as to how communications can help. You can read our article at <a title="Top Four Challenges HR is Facing in 2012...and How Communications Can Help" href="http://www.writetarget.com/top_four_challenges_HR_is_facing_in_2012.pdf" target="_blank">http://www.writetarget.com/top_four_challenges_HR_is_facing_in_2012.pdf</a>. Hope our tips and examples help you to make 2012 one of the best ever!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Communications Lesson from a Groundhog</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/communications-lesson-from-a-groundhog/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Feb 2012 17:21:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=147</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We’re all a buzz about Punxsutawney Phil and six more weeks of winter. (Although, we’re not certain winter has even started here in Ohio.)

But besides the little rodent, this day brings thoughts of Bill Murray and the ’93 movie <em>Groundhog Day</em>. In the movie, a weatherman finds himself reliving the same day (Groundhog Day) over and over again. It’s so repetitive that you’re able to predict his whole day.

<strong>How repetitive are you with your messages?</strong> Are employees able to repeat the messages clearly? In today’s overloaded environment, you have to tell someone something about seven times before they actually remember it. <em>Seven times!</em> Not once or twice… nope, seven times.

<strong>Tip:</strong> Use the same message but repurpose it through different communication vehicles to make sure the message is out there multiple times. One message; seven different times.
<ul>
	<li>Company newsletter</li>
	<li>Email reminder</li>
	<li>Bulletin board poster</li>
	<li>Tweet</li>
	<li>Flyer on bathroom stall doors (We want someone to use this one!)</li>
	<li>Company-wide voicemail</li>
	<li>Posting in break rooms</li>
</ul>
The next time you’re coming up with your communications plan, think of all the ways you can reuse your message — seven times – in your company. Your communications have to be seen to be understood. Seven times! Did we say seven?

<em>By the way… We said “seven times” seven different times in this post. Did you get the message?</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>147</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-02 17:21:26</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-02 17:21:26</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>communications-lesson-from-a-groundhog</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Health Care Is Not Our Native Language</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/health-care-is-not-our-native-language/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 07 Feb 2012 19:11:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=150</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Coinsurance, out-of-pocket maximum, deductible, oh my! </em></strong>

Write On Target is in the throes of picking its health plan for 2012. And although we pride ourselves on knowing a lot about health care, we are having trouble deciphering some of the jargon-ridden materials. Imagine how your employees feel. Remember: Confusion leads to frustration which leads to a low opinion of valuable benefits.

 <em>So how do you get away from jargon? </em>

<strong><em> </em></strong><strong>Write it the way you’d say it...</strong> in plain English. (Or, in the dialect most common to your audience.)

 The more complex the information, the more important it is that you speak clearly in plain language. Ask yourself these two questions to avoid falling into the jargon trap:
<ol>
	<li>Does the average person know the terminology being used?</li>
	<li>Is this how I would explain it in a normal conversation?</li>
</ol>
 If you answer no to either or both questions… rewrite until you get it right.

 <em>Tip: </em>Whenever you grapple with writing a particularly complex section, sit down and explain the concept to someone outside the HR department. Play with the wording until it makes perfect sense to your volunteer, and then write down what you said.

 <em>More tips on how to write in plain language to come in future blogs. </em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Does Coinsurance Translate?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/does-coinsurance-translate/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Feb 2012 21:42:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=154</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hola. Salut. Hallo. Привет. Hej.

Most of us will recognize one of the above as meaning “Hello.” Albeit the Russian one stumped a few of us; but with an accompanied wave of the hand, we would have figured it out.

<strong>Would the translation of HR buzz words hold up as well?</strong> Many terms are barely in the English dictionary. And what gesture could possibly make “coinsurance” understandable?

In honor of February being the month to celebrate diversity,<strong> </strong>we’re wondering how you handle communicating with your diverse workforce. Whether it’s a mix of races, cultures or generations, you have communication barriers that may interfere with understanding.

<strong><em>Translating is great…unless deductible means pig in Spanish. </em></strong>Take the extra step to ensure your translations are accurate. Find someone within your organization who understands the native language and culture to review the piece you’ve translated. Not everything translated stays in the same context. Some pieces may have to be rewritten even after translation to ensure the message is truly accurate and understandable.

<strong><em>Consider your communication vehicles.</em></strong> We all read messages through different avenues – some like electronic messages through email or posted online; while others prefer a printed piece that they can take home. Get a pulse of what your employees prefer. You don’t have to use every single communication vehicle available to you, but consider what’s out there and repurpose your messages to reach the majority of your audiences.

Embrace the diversity of your workforce and try new ways of communicating to your employees.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-09 21:42:14</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>does-coinsurance-translate</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Feelin’ Mushy On Valentine’s Day…</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/feelin-mushy-on-valentines-day/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Feb 2012 18:05:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=161</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/heart11.gif"><img class="alignright  wp-image-167" title="heart1" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/heart11.gif?w=263" alt="" width="165" height="179" /></a></em></strong>

I consider myself one of the luckiest business owners in the world. We have fabulous clients who work with us year after year and truly treat us as valuable members of their HR team.  We can share ideas freely and be forthright at all times. I think they appreciate our honesty because they realize we are always looking out for their best interests.  In turn, our clients have always looked out for us. In fact, throughout our 18 years, almost all our new business has come through word of mouth. Believe me, I realize not many companies can say that and I truly appreciate their loyal support.

And then there is the Write On Target team.  What a group! They are smart, funny, creative and some of the most dedicated folks you’ll ever meet! Jennifer puts her heart and soul into her writing. She’s constantly tweaking a piece from the first draft through final layout to make it just perfect. Kelly handles some of our largest clients with ease, thanks to her steady focus and incredible organizational skills. Her clients absolutely love her. Julie is both left- and right-brained, using her creative skills to design eye-catching materials then suddenly shifting gears to negotiate the best printing or fulfillment price. How does she do that? And Becky keeps the place going by making sure our invoices are correct and our bills are paid.  (Personally, I wouldn’t want her job…numbers are not my friend!) And finally, we have our new team member, Paula, who will help spread the word about the incredible talents of the WOT team throughout the HR community. 

When I started Write On Target 18 years ago in my living room, I never dreamed I’d be surrounded by such talented, warm and loving people.  So this is my Valentine to the WOT team …thanks for sharing your unique talents and skills. Thanks for your hard work and tireless commitment to giving 110% to our clients. But mostly, thanks for being you.  I don’t know what I’d do without each and every one of you. You are so much more than coworkers. You are my extended family.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Do Your Compliance Docs Speak The Same Language?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/do-your-compliance-docs-speak-the-same-language/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Feb 2012 15:10:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=174</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[An interesting <strong><a href="http://www.shrm.org/hrdisciplines/benefits/Articles/Pages/PrepareforSBCs.aspx">article</a> </strong>on the Society of Human Resource Management (SHRM) website refers to the final rulings issued last week for Summary of Benefits and Coverage documents, which will need to be sent to current and potential health plan participants after enrollment this fall.

Many employers are expecting their health carriers to handle the design and distribution of the federally required summary documents. At the same time, the article states “81 percent of U.S. employers plan to update their health care Summary Plan Descriptions (SPDs) in 2012 to incorporate changes in plan design and new coverage requirements under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA).” according to a recent study by HighRoads.

Although Summary of Benefits and Coverage notices and SPDs are two different types of compliance documents, we’d like to make a strong suggestion. If you’re planning on updating your SPDs, <strong>make sure the language in your SPDs matches the language in your Summary of Benefits and Coverage documents.</strong> And as the article states, don’t forget “the PPACA places an increased focus on the importance of accurate, timely and easy-to-read communication documents.”

That’s a tall order. But SPDs can be written to be user-friendly and easy to understand. For some inside tips, download our paper, <strong><em><a href="http://www.writetarget.com/SPD_white%20paper.pdf">SPDs…Taking Yours from Legalese to Read with Ease</a>. </em></strong> Then take a deep breath and add this to your ever-growing “to do” list.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	<item>
		<title>Our Favorite Week… Leading to a Noble Affair</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/our-favorite-week-leading-to-a-noble-affair/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Feb 2012 18:09:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=179</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>By Jennifer Witman</strong></em>

This week is our favorite because we get to use our talents to help a noble cause make money.

We met the non-profit group, <strong>The Noble Circle Project,</strong> over seven years ago when my friend Lisa, who at age 35 and two weeks a new mom, was told she had stage 4 breast cancer and about two years to live. Lisa didn’t accept that diagnosis. She sought out the best doctors, oncologists and medicine, and along the way found The Noble Circle Project. I truly believe this group of women (maybe 30 at the time) is why Lisa outlived her diagnosis – by two beautiful years. 

The Noble Circle Project was started by eight women exploring their options in healing. So they created an intimate and caring community that brings together hope, inspiration, empowerment <em>and</em> healing… and it all begins with one weekend. Twice a year 30 new women sign up to attend a wellness retreat where they learn about whole-foods nutrition, complementary healing techniques, such as, qigong, and group support. Then during 10 weeks of follow-up classes, they practice what they learn. Alumnae members also join monthly to continue their learning and practicing.  

What gets us excited about The Noble Circle Project, which has grown to over 220 women, is that the retreat and 10-week classes are <em>completely</em> run by the women of the group – the women undergoing treatments, losing their hair, and trying to keep their families and friends from losing hope. And every day this week, we get to see many of these inspiring women as they get ready for their annual fundraiser, the <em>AWear Affair</em> Fashion Show and Luncheon.

As you can imagine, seeing these women reminds us of the frailty of life. How in one moment a diagnosis can change your life forever. But the magic of Noble Circle is they teach you to not be frail. Rather it’s about relying on your inner strength to reclaim your health and embrace a changing life…<em>one that’s going to be</em> <em>better</em>.

To be so dignified, gracious, splendid… in every meaning of the word – noble. We are blessed to know this group of women and to help them in the smallest of possible ways in their journey.

<em>You can learn more about The Noble Circle Project at </em><a href="http://www.noblecircle.org/"><em>www.noblecircle.org</em></a><em>. </em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Is it worthwhile to compare your plans to the Marketplace options?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/?p=679</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Nov 2013 15:04:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=679</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></p><p>In addition to the sending the required health exchange notice to employees on October 1, some of our clients have been providing customized information about health care reform to their employees including:</p><ul><li>Training for HR and other leaders about the changes being made in 2014 due to health care reform (eligibility, plan design, etc.).</li><li>Talking points for HR and senior leaders to address employees’ questions.</li><li>Q&amp;As, articles and slides for employees to explain how health care reform specifically impacts their organization.</li><li>Postcards to homes about the impact of health care reform for spouses as well as employees.</li><li>Posters about the exchange notice in case an employee didn’t receive their notice (also served as a reminder for HR to provide the notice to new hires in a timely manner).</li></ul><p>However, Robert Schuldt II, Director of Compensation and Benefits at Brunswick Corporation, took it one step further. For portions of his workforce where data was available, he provided a side-by-side cost comparison between one of his company’s medical plan options to an actuarially comparable Marketplace option. Rob explains, “I’d heard feedback from a few of our locations that some employees thought health care coverage through the Marketplace would be free. I wanted to clear up that misconception, but there was also a more important reason. I wanted our employees to see the value of our benefits.  We have done quite a bit of benchmarking and, in fact, our benefits rank high among competitive practices. Over the past few years, we’ve shared the benchmarking results, as well as listing Brunswick’s contribution amount next to the employee’s portion. Furthermore, we just completed our employee opinion survey and coupled with open enrollment, I knew our benefit programs were top of mind for employees.  Therefore, I saw the introduction of the Marketplace options as another opportunity to illustrate the value of our benefits.”</p><p>He started by reviewing the <a title="Marketplace Premiums" href="http://aspe.hhs.gov/health/reports/2013/marketplacepremiums/ib_marketplace_premiums.cfm" target="_blank">premiums</a> individuals would pay for the federal Marketplace options, available on the Health and Human Services website. He then pulled together the premium amounts for representative single and family coverage levels for the comparable plan option in eight of his major locations. Since costs on the Marketplace vary by age and zip code, he listed multiple examples for each location. For example in Chicago, single coverage was priced out for a 25, 45 and 55 year old in Cook County and Lake County. Prices for the Marketplace plan ranged from $165.17 up to $378.43 per month. Brunswick’s comparable plan was 75 to 90 percent less. Big difference! It was even more dramatic with family coverage.</p><p>So Rob put together a communication that showed the comparison and added the following points:</p><ul><li>That the scenarios did not include any potential subsidy under the Marketplace options but that generally Brunswick employees wouldn’t  be eligible for a subsidy if eligible under Brunswick plans, and</li><li>Other factors that employees need to consider with the Marketplace are the actual deductibles and <br />out of pocket maximums (which can be significant) and network of doctors and hospitals (which can <br />be limiting).</li></ul><p>Rob provided both the plan cost comparison flyer and a few slides to each of the applicable locations to use during their open enrollment meetings…which are going on now. He said, “so far, employees are having <br />‘ah-ha moments’ when they see the difference in cost.” For Rob, this proved to be a worthwhile tactic and he plans to continue his marketing efforts throughout 2014 to increase understanding and appreciation for the value of the benefits Brunswick provides to its employees.</p><p><br /> <i>Editor’s Note:<br /></i><i>I have not looked at the Marketplace plans, but was shocked to find out that in some cases the family deductible is $12,700 versus comparable employer medical plan options that have a $3,000 deductible. Will enrollees look at deductibles? Or will they just look for the lowest cost plan? That kind of difference, coupled with narrower provider networks for the Marketplace plans has me worried. There has been so much criticism of “Obamacare” in the rollout. What will happen when folks start using the plans and find out they have high deductibles to meet? It will be interesting…</i></p>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Tout Your &quot;Hidden&quot; Benefits with These 5 Tips</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/tout-your-hidden-benefits-with-these-5-communication-tips/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Jan 2012 23:21:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetarget.wordpress.com/?p=13</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>New Year’s Resolutions Are the Water Cooler Talk. Join the Conversation. </strong>

We know it seems too easy to use this as a hook. But, there truly is no better time to tout your company’s health, wellness and financial programs – those hidden, under-used programs — than at the beginning of the year.
<ul>
	<li><strong>Resolutions are top of mind.</strong> You have your employees’ attention. They are open at this time to receiving information and engaging in programs that can help them lose weight, save money and manage stress.</li>
	<li><strong>Resolutions are hard to keep. </strong>More than half of us will give up on our resolutions by February, if not already. You’ll be the hero if you have the solution to help employees keep theirs, for once!</li>
</ul>
<strong>5 Tips to Use Today</strong>

With each of these communications tasks, remember: Keep it simple. Your communications strategy is to let employees know these health, wellness and financial programs exist. It’s not to give every detail or nuance of every HR and benefit program. But do give clear direction on where employees can learn more.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Create an Email / Newsletter Article –</strong> List out the top resolutions (search online for a listing) then direct employees to your company’s specific HR and benefit programs that can help. It may be your EAP, company wellness programs, medical plan wellness programs, 401(k) vendor’s financial advisor tools, or insurance plan's legal services. Do your research. You may have to remind yourself of what’s available. Then use links within your email to take employees directly to each program website, or where they can go to find more information.</li>
	<li><strong>Distribute a Repurposed Flyer –</strong> Engage employees who don’t have a desk. Take the email/newsletter content from above and turn it into a flyer that can be distributed at employee meetings, in employee mailboxes, in the company cafeteria or in other meeting areas. Heck put one inside each bathroom stall. Talk about undivided attention!</li>
	<li><strong>Set Up a “Tell Me Your Resolution. I’ll Tell You How to Succeed” Booth</strong> – Yes a booth...somewhat. Set up within your company cafeteria, general gathering area or at your building’s front door during lunch hours (catch employees on their way to restaurant row). All you need is a table, poster, print outs of program materials (all vendors have information online) and a laptop. You’ll be fully equipped to talk about the relevant HR and benefit programs.</li>
	<li><strong>Update Your Intranet/Internet –</strong> Be sure the home page of your employee and benefits websites include links and maybe even features of all of your health, wellness and financial programs.</li>
	<li><strong>Remember Employees Are Just Like You – </strong>No matter the department, title or job responsibilities, we all struggle to keep our resolutions. Use your communication tools and vendor resources to help your employees stay on track. Who knows…it just might help you to stay focused as well!</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Don’t Be Head of the Class</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/dont-be-head-of-the-class/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Feb 2012 14:01:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=191</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Another lesson in plain language…</em></strong>

For communications to be understood, your writing needs to be direct, familiar and concise. We’ve talked about jargon and how to avoid it. Another way to improve readability is to run a grade-level check on your material.

In general, most adults read at the sixth to eighth grade level. Think <em>TV Guide</em>, <em>Reader’s Digest</em> and most popular novels. Business publications, <em>Time Magazine</em> and <em>Newsweek</em> are written at the 10+ grade level. Anything from the government or a lawyer is over grade 20.

<em>Tip:</em> It’s possible to obtain good readability scores even with gobbledygook – what we call the language necessary for summary plan descriptions. Aim to keep most of your text to shorter sentences. Typically, a sentence over 14 words is too long.

<strong><em>How to check the grade-level:</em></strong>

The Flesch-Kincaid grade level can be found in Microsoft Word’s Spelling and Grammar tool. Within reason, you should aim for between sixth to eighth grade. 

<em>Remember:</em> Confusion leads to frustration which leads to a low opinion of valuable programs.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>6 Months Later and We’re Talkin’ Post-disaster Benefits Again</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/6-months-later-and-were-talkin-post-disaster-benefits-again/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Mar 2012 21:26:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=196</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Six months ago, I posted the following on the LinkedIn group, <a title="HR Communications Th@t Work" href="http://www.linkedin.com/groups/Great-idea-postHurricane-benefits-communications-2006357.S.68599040?qid=644c25db-3517-40bf-9585-996dee432cfe&amp;goback=%2Egna_2006357">HR Communications Th@t Work</a>:

<em><strong>Great idea for post-hurricane benefits communications
</strong>A client asked us to prepare an important post-hurricane communications piece. It turns out that their 401(k) vendor was getting calls from employees wondering if they could take a hardship withdrawal. She wanted to get a one-page flyer out to explain the rules around hardship withdrawals and also discuss the possibility of the government issuing a Special Emergency Hurricane Withdrawal (which hasn't happened yet). We suggested the addition of a piece about the support available through the EAP. We got it done in a day and out to employees. Thought I'd share this idea with others. Benefits communications is best when it's timely, useful and to the point. </em>

Unfortunately, that same client is faced with a similar communication again…this time due to the devastation inflicted by the Midwest tornadoes this past weekend. Natural disasters like hurricanes and tornadoes literally turn people’s lives upside down. As an HR communicator, you can lend a helping hand. Prepare a quick-read one-page flyer to help direct employees to the right resources…whether it’s how to get a duplicate ID card, reach out for support through the EAP or tap into their 401(k) account. Plus, take the opportunity to shine the light on under-used programs, such as the 24/7 nurseline, discounts on eyewear and other “perks” that come along with your standard benefits.

If your locations weren’t impacted by the recent tornadoes, you’re lucky. But why wait? Take this time to create a flyer so you are prepared if a disaster hits. In the meantime, it wouldn’t hurt to post it on your website and bring it to employees’ attention so they know where to go to pull the information when they need it. As I said six months ago, “benefits communications is best when it’s timely, useful and to the point.”]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>When is the Best Time to Communicate?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/when-is-the-best-time-to-communicate/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Mar 2012 12:56:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=212</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>By Elizabeth Borton</strong></em>

This past Sunday morning, my six year old grandson was standing next to my bed, asking if we could go downstairs to have a cup of tea (it’s our bonding ritual when he spends the night). I opened one eye, looked at the clock and saw it was 6:30 a.m. – or was it? You see, our clocks “sprang forward” one hour Saturday night. Lucky for Sam, it was actually 7:30 in the morning.

It got me thinking about the perception of time. At many of my speaking engagements, folks ask about the timing of their HR communications. They want to know how far in advance they should communicate a change. My answer is that it depends on many factors.

The following are some guidelines to keep in mind:
<ul>
	<li>If your communication is about an action employees need to take, do not send it to them until they can take the action.</li>
	<li>If you are dealing with something like annual enrollment that lasts a couple weeks, post reminders throughout the period on your website, through posters and so forth to keep the momentum going.</li>
	<li>If you are making big changes, such as introducing a new HSA medical plan or changing investment options in the 401(k), then you’ll want to start educating employees about the change prior to the effective date or enrollment. I’d suggest starting a series of communications one to two months in advance, depending on the complexity of the change. (Keep in mind, that people absorb information better if it is delivered to them in small bites, rather than one gigantic communications package.)</li>
	<li>If you are making big changes to the salaried population that you hope to negotiate into union contracts, you might want to start educating employees about the upcoming changes prior to the union talks. In this way, you’ll avoid misinformation trickling into the rumor mill.</li>
	<li>However, HR communications isn’t all about changes. Employees need to understand how to access and use the plans and services you provide. So it is important to communicate with employees throughout the year, either through mass communications or more targeted messaging to specific groups (e.g. educating managers around merit pay increases or bonus payouts). Remember, you don’t want to just “push” information out. You need to have a clear, concise website where employees can “pull” information when they need it.</li>
	<li>It’s important to coordinate timing with Corporate Communications. For example, you don’t want to send out total rewards statements to tell employees how valuable they are to the organization in the same week that a major plant shutdown is announced.</li>
	<li>And of course, you need to keep in mind the various deadlines to send out compliance documents.</li>
</ul>
Whew! That’s a lot to consider, and it’s just the tip of the iceberg. How do you get your arms around all these timing issues? PLAN! An annual communications plan and calendar is essential. We’ll tackle that issue in our next blog. In the meantime, enjoy the spring weather and the extra hour of daylight!]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>when-is-the-best-time-to-communicate</wp:post_name>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Before You Start Writing, Plan, Plan, Plan</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/before-you-start-writing-plan-plan-plan/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 20 Mar 2012 21:35:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=219</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We know. Planning is not the sexiest part of marketing and communications, but it is probably the most important.

Whether you’re talking about a major annual enrollment campaign, or just a 140-character tweet, you have to take a moment to think about what you want to accomplish. Otherwise you’ll be throwing your time, energy and budget at communications with no results.

Before ever putting finger to keyboard, write up a plan. Take some time to think through:
<ul>
	<li>what you hope to achieve (objective)</li>
	<li>who can bring about your desired result (audience)</li>
	<li>what they need to be told to motivate action (key message)</li>
	<li>the best way to reach your audience (vehicle)</li>
	<li>when to get the message across and how often (timing)</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>A quick overview:
</em></strong><strong>Objectives</strong>: Define meaningful and measurable goals so you can show results for your efforts. It’s best if you can show how your objectives support the company’s overall objectives.

<strong>Audience</strong>: In addition to your obvious target audience, consider those who might influence your target as well as those who could help out as messengers or champions.

<strong>Key messages: </strong>Audiences have very short attention spans, so don’t overwhelm them with too much information. Try to stick to three to five key messages then let them know where they can go for more details.

<strong>Vehicle</strong>: Think outside the box. What vehicles are available to you? Which are preferred by your target audience? Which can you afford? The key is to use as many vehicles as you can so you can get the key messages out as often as possible. Which brings us to….

<strong>Timing</strong>: You need to reach your target audience at least seven times before the key messages start to sink in. How do you do that? By repurposing the same information through various vehicles (e.g. postcard, intranet site, poster, brochure, employee meetings, blog, twitter, etc.) We covered more about timing in our post on <span style="text-decoration:underline;"><a href="http://http://writetargetblog.com/2012/02/02/communications-lesson-from-a-groundhog/">Ground Hog Day</a></span>.

<strong>Creating an annual calendar is the best approach
</strong>Ideally, you should create an integrated HR communications calendar at the beginning of the year. Consider all the upcoming initiatives and notification requirements for every area of HR including compensation, talent management and benefits. It will be a bit overwhelming at first, but it will help you to see the whole picture and prioritize your efforts. For example, some messages may be able to be combined. Some may be handled through a targeted mailing to a specific group. Some may only be a notification posted on the intranet. The important thing is to plan ahead so you can maximize your time, energy and budget.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_id>58</wp:comment_id>

	<item>
		<title>It’s All in the K.I.S.S.</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/its-all-in-the-k-i-s-s/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 27 Mar 2012 18:55:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=225</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Keep It Short and Simple (K.I.S.S.)</em></strong>

Attention spans are shrinking by the minute. Long gone are the days of leisurely reading something cover to cover. Today, you’ve got a millisecond to grab your audience. Then, if you’re lucky, another second to get them reading. That’s why K.I.S.S. is important.

Tips for keeping it short and simple…
Think <em>USA Today</em> not <em>Wall Street Journal</em>. Don’t be a novelist. Use bite size pieces of information. Subheads help break up long copy.

Omit needless words. If readers have to diagram sentences to figure out what you’re saying, you’ve failed. Aim for 14 words per sentence.

Avoid third person (employee, retiree, he and she). Write directly to your audience by using “you” and “your” instead.

Use active language. Passive writing confuses readers and weakens the message, especially if giving direction. (In active language, the actor comes before the action.)
<strong>PASSIVE:</strong> SPDs were distributed by the benefits department on January 1.
<strong>ACTIVE:</strong> The benefits department distributed SPDs on January 1.
<strong>PASSIVE:</strong> Your biometrics should be measured every year.
<strong>ACTIVE:</strong> (Implied you) Measure your biometrics every year.

Do your communications pass the K.I.S.S. test?]]></content:encoded>
