	<item>
		<title>Cruising and Writing Tip 2: Get to Know the Locals</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/cruising-and-writing-tip-2-get-to-know-the-locals/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Apr 2012 20:58:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=254</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>By Elizabeth Borton</strong></em>

Back in <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/01/24/living-on-a-boat-hr-communications/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">January</span></a> I wrote a blog about how living on a boat helped me to become a better HR communicator. The first lesson I covered is that “less is more.” Today, I’d like to discuss the importance of getting to know the locals.

One of our favorite things about cruising was meeting folks along the way. In fact, as we traveled through the Erie Canal, many of the small towns had official greeters to welcome us as we tied up for the evening. They’d give us directions to the local grocery or laudromat, answer our questions and give us tips on local sites or restaurants. One night, we tied up next to a park where some fellows were fishing. At first, my husband was a bit skeptical because the guys looked a bit “fishy” (pun fully intended). But soon, he started chatting it up and told them how he was worried because we were running low on diesel and many of the marinas seemed to be closed. One of the fellows offered to drive Bill to the store to get a gas can then took him to a station that had diesel. We thanked him and offered money but he wouldn’t take it. To our surprise, he returned that evening with two prime rib dinners. Turns out he was a cook at a local restaurant. As you can see, getting to know the locals really paid off!

The same is true in your HR communications. Before you start writing, make sure you understand your audience and their needs. The simplest trick is to put yourself in their shoes. How does the information impact them? Why should they be motivated to act? Are you speaking their language? Are you being as direct as possible? (Targeted communications create better results than off-the-shelf, generic options that skim out details just so materials apply to everyone.) And for heaven’s sake, if you have bad news to tell, tell it. Don’t bury it in a bunch of corporate mumbo jumbo. Be direct, tell the bad news and the business reason for the decision and move on. Your employees may not like it, but they will appreciate being treated as adults.

It comes down to respect. When you take the time to know your audience you’re in a better position to communicate. Once you communicate well and make an emotional connection, you’ll be able to increase engagement and drive behavior. As you can see, getting to know the locals really does pay off!

PS. Are you in the Cincinnati area? Come to the <a href="https://custom.cvent.com/74D4BDC75E02408884096BFFFCFA8E15/files/51df0a3d6a554c29ba7779aa5845040f.pdf"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">HR Collaborative conference</span></a> on April 18 to hear my speech “How Living on a Boat Made Me a Better HR Communicator.” I’d love to meet you in person!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Just Because You Like a Word…</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/just-because-you-like-a-word/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Apr 2012 17:46:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=262</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Doesn’t mean you should use it.</em></strong>

<strong>By: Jennifer Witman</strong>

Back when I worked in the marcom department of a computer company, our staff of writers loved the word cornucopia. So much so, we would find a way to use it in the ads just to see which ones would pass through our editor. In any given week that could be 30 to 50 ads. That’s a cornucopia of opportunities!

Only once did the word make it to publication. Oh the glee to have it be my ad. What an award-winning use. So I thought… until I saw it in print. The word cliché doesn’t pay justice to how bad a decision that was.

<strong>Tip:</strong> We only have a short time to grab someone’s attention and even less time to keep it. Using useless words wastes precious time. Be conscious to make every word count. If a better word (ahem, even shorter one) does the trick, use it.

Seriously, cornucopia?!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>262</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-04-25 17:46:23</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-04-25 17:46:23</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>just-because-you-like-a-word</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="blog"><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="communication-in-the-workplace"><![CDATA[communication in the workplace]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="communication-strategies"><![CDATA[communication strategies]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="communication-tips"><![CDATA[Communication Tips]]></category>

	<item>
		<title>Six Ways to Give Your Brain a Spring Break</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/six-ways-to-give-your-brain-a-spring-break/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 May 2012 13:35:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=267</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>By Elizabeth Borton</strong></em>

Have you ever had “writer’s block?” When you just can’t come up with the words, the deadline is looming and you start to panic? It’s happened to me plenty of times.  I find it’s particularly true in the spring. The weather warms up, flowers are blooming and my mind starts wandering. Sound familiar? 

Try these tips to give your brain a spring break.
<ol>
	<li><strong>Take a walk outside. </strong>Nothing like a change in scenery to change your perspective. Just relax and take it all in…the sights, the sounds, the smells…the whole sweet soup of springtime. By taking your mind off the task at hand, you’ll give your subconscious a chance to work on the problem and deliver a solution.</li>
	<li><strong>Just breathe.</strong> Hmm…sounds easy doesn’t it? Breathing is something we take for granted. But have you ever closed your eyes and really focused on your breathing for five minutes? Not so easy to do if you’re a beginner, but boy is it relaxing. I highly recommend breathing (meditating) to all my friends!</li>
	<li><strong>Switch gears.</strong> Surely you have other tasks on your “to-do” list. Give your brain a break by focusing it elsewhere. When you come back to the writing challenge you just may have some fresh ideas.</li>
	<li><strong>Carry a notebook.</strong> It doesn’t have to be fancy. Heck, a napkin will do. Just be prepared. Because once you relax your brain, the ideas will pop up at the strangest times. I keep one in my car, next to my bed and of course, at my desk.</li>
	<li><strong>Start in the middle.</strong> Who said you have to start with an award-winning headline or pithy opening statement? Start with some of the factual parts of your writing that are easy to compose. You can circle back to your witty headline once you get on a roll.</li>
	<li><strong>Just do it. </strong>American poet William Stafford offers this advice, "There is no such thing as writer's block for writers whose standards are low enough."  I love this quote. Not because I think you should write terrible copy, but because you shouldn’t take yourself too seriously. Sometimes you just have to start putting words on paper. You’ll find it’s a whole lot easier and way less stressful to edit something than to stare at a blank screen.<strong></strong></li>
</ol>
The next time your mind starts wandering, don’t fight it…give your brain a spring break.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Get Out of Your Head and Into My Shoes</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/get-out-of-your-head-and-into-my-shoes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 May 2012 17:23:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=272</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In communications there is often a gap between what HR wants to tell and what employees want to hear. Case in point… You may need to communicate that your company’s switching medical plans. In doing so, you feel compelled to explain the business purpose behind it. Whereas employees simply want to know how this impacts them and what they need to do.

How do you shift gears from focusing on what you want to tell? Put yourself in the reader’s shoes. Think from an employee’s point of view — not yours and not the company’s. 

It’s not always easy. Sometimes leadership can strongly encourage you to tell the story the way they see it. If you’re in a position where you have to include the company’s point of view, put it in a side bar or move it to the bottom. It can be included but not be the primary focus.

<strong><em>Tip! </em></strong>If you want an employee to do something, think WIIFM — What’s in it for me (the employee)?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>You Can’t Handle the Truth!</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/you-cant-handle-the-truth/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 May 2012 13:36:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=280</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Um, yes I can. And so can employees.  

<strong>Don’t bury bad news. </strong>Put it up front and center. Like a Band-Aid, rip it off, tell it outright. But then follow it up with the business reason. Employees may not like the news, but give them the opportunity to process it and understand it.

<strong>“Because I said so” isn’t a business reason. </strong>But neither is “In an effort to manage rising costs, we’re changing our health insurance plan.” OK, so that is a reason. But on its own, it says nothing to the employee. (And, ahem, we’ve been guilty of using that line.) Give it to them straight, but in a meaningful way. In a few sentences, you can explain how changing plans will help save money for everyone and the benefits of the new plan(s).

<em>Bottom line: Change is hard for most of us. But explain the “why” in a meaningful way and employees might be more likely to accept it. </em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>280</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>you-cant-handle-the-truth</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Your Employees Need the Sun</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/your-employees-need-the-sun/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 May 2012 16:44:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=283</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We recently attended a lecture about leading extraordinary performance. The session reinforced the comparison of leadership to the Heliotropic effect. The Heliotropic effect is when plants move to follow the sun.

How does this apply to leadership? Studies show that employees will move toward positive, engaged leadership. So how do you help employees see leadership in this light?

<strong>Show leaders as being real people… involved and participating.</strong> Highlight leadership participating in the exact same initiatives that you roll out to employees – wellness events, benefits fairs, 401k education lunches, etc. As an employee, wouldn’t it be great to see leadership trying to get the same amount of steps on their pedometer as you? Suddenly, we all have something in common.

<em>Ideas for visibility: </em>Maybe have leaders and managers run the sign-up desk for the biometrics screening one day, or create a testimonial about one of the leaders attending a safety training course out on the plant floor. One of our clients went so far as to have senior leaders put together the wellness series where each leader talks about a lifestyle change they’ve made and how they did it. Premise being that even the top dogs struggle with finding time to fit in exercise and took three times to successfully quit smoking. <em></em>

<strong>WARNING: Engagement is not forced involvement.</strong> There are many, many companies out there who specialize in creating an engaged workforce. All we’re talking about here is spotlighting the engaged leaders you already have. An engaged leader says, “I’m sold; sign me up; this is an awesome idea; I fully support this organization.” If a senior leader isn’t supportive of an initiative, then consider showcasing an excited supervisor or supportive HR staff member.

<em>Remember, plants not only seek out the sun, they turn their faces to it and embrace it. </em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>283</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>your-employees-need-the-sun</wp:post_name>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="communication-in-the-workplace"><![CDATA[communication in the workplace]]></category>

	<item>
		<title>Four Months ’Til It All Breaks Loose</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/four-months-til-it-all-breaks-loose/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Jun 2012 15:22:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=287</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Typical annual enrollment season is only four months away. We know you’d rather be sitting on your deck with a Mojito than thinking about what’s going to happen in October. So would we. Oh wait… this is what we do for a living.

Fact is annual enrollment will be here before we know it and we’ve already started preparing with many clients. Below are some of the tasks we’re doing now that may help you as you prepare.

<strong>Creating the communications plan:
</strong>Once you have an idea of the changes for 2013, you should start drafting your <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/03/20/before-you-start-writing-plan-plan-plan/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">communications plan</span></a>. Think through:
<ul>
	<li>What you hope to achieve (objective).</li>
	<li>Who can bring about your desired result (audience).</li>
	<li>What they need told to be motivated to action (message).</li>
	<li>The best way to reach your audience (vehicle).</li>
	<li>When to get the message across and how often (timing).</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>Tip!</em></strong> Get approval and buy-in now. Your plan will drive your communications throughout the entire AE season. So spend some quality time drafting it, then get immediate approval and buy-in from leaders throughout the organization. It will make your job of executing the plan smoother.

<strong> </strong><strong>Gathering the communications team:
</strong>Who will execute the plan? Find the players and assign roles and responsibilities. At a high-level you’ll need:
<ul>
	<li>Executor of the plan</li>
	<li>Writer/content provider or subject matter expert(s)</li>
	<li>Designer/IT support</li>
	<li>Reviewer(s)</li>
	<li>Final decision-maker (ahem, tie-breaker)</li>
</ul>
You may even consider including some folks outside of HR or corporate communications to be on the team. What better way to see if your messages are clear but by running them by an actual employee?!

<strong>Creating the production schedules:
</strong>Writing, coordinating, reviewing and delivering communications are probably not the only job you have for annual enrollment. Production schedules are a great way for you and the team to schedule your time with your other umpteen to do’s.

To create a production schedule, you start with the date you plan to deliver the piece of communication and work backward, slotting time for:
<ul>
	<li>Content gathering</li>
	<li>Writing</li>
	<li>Design (if applicable)</li>
	<li>Rounds of reviews</li>
	<li>Printing/production</li>
	<li>Distribution</li>
</ul>
It’s never too early to get the preparations started. And we’re always here if you need help – providing tips and tricks of the trade to help you execute communications that are “right<em> </em>on target.”]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>And Some Say Punctuation Doesn’t Matter.</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/and-some-say-punctuation-doesnt-matter/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Jun 2012 16:24:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=295</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ We think Grandpa would say punctuation can make all the difference…

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/grandpa1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-301" title="grandpa" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/grandpa1.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="229" /></a>

We talk a lot about using plain language and writing at the sixth to eighth grade level. But equally important to conveying your message is the punctuation you use.

 Does anyone really believe Rachael Ray eats her family or her dog…?

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/rachel-ray2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-302" title="rachel ray" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/rachel-ray2.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="267" /></a>

If you’re ever in doubt about proper punctuation, turn to one of our favorite references for help…

<a href="http://www.apstylebook.com">AP Stylebook </a>
<a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Grammar-Reference-Guide-CareerTrack/dp/1933328541">The Grammar Reference Guide</a>
<a href="http://grammar.quickanddirtytips.com">Grammar Girl™ Quick and Dirty Tricks™</a>
<a href="http://dictionary.reference.com">Dictionary.com</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>295</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-06-06 16:24:55</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-06-06 16:24:55</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>and-some-say-punctuation-doesnt-matter</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
		<title>Look to the Pyramid for the Point</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/look-to-the-pyramid-for-the-point/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jun 2012 15:08:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=311</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When employees receive any piece of communication, they only want to know three things:
<ol>
	<li>What is this about?</li>
	<li>How does it impact me?</li>
	<li>What do I have to do? </li>
</ol>
That’s why we use a unique pyramid approach so our communications get to the point — focusing on the “need to know,” “nice to know,” then “benefit geek” (required legal language) last.

<strong><a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb2.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-315" title="Pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb2.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="300" height="214" /></a></strong>

<strong></strong> 

<strong></strong> 

<strong></strong> 

<strong></strong> 

<strong></strong> 

<strong></strong> <strong>Need to know: the what, how, when</strong>
<ul>
	<li>What’s happening</li>
	<li>What do I need to do</li>
	<li>How to do it</li>
	<li>Deadline to take action</li>
	<li>Information needed to make decision</li>
</ul>
<em>Should be able to scan and get these answers</em>

<strong>Nice to know: the why</strong><strong></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Why action is being required</li>
	<li>Why a change is occurring</li>
	<li>The company’s position</li>
</ul>
<em>Keep to sidebars or sectioned-off areas</em>

<strong>Benefit geek: everything else</strong><strong></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Detailed “jargon” required for legal reasons or to provide for further explanation</li>
	<li>If including legal notices, tell them no action is required</li>
</ul>
<em>Keep to footnotes or as links to other documents for more information</em>

If we force people to search for the message, the message will never be found.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Did You Say Something??</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/did-you-say-something/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Jun 2012 15:26:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=337</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>“I couldn’t hear you over the 36,972 other messages I’ve heard today.”</em>

In its purest sense, communication means putting one’s ideas across to another — which cannot happen if the audience never receives what we’re putting out there. Or worse, the audience receives the communication, but doesn’t understand it the way we intended.

<em>Ahhh</em>… the challengers of effective communications — those nasty things called barriers that inhibit, prohibit and just plain get in the way. Here’s what barriers look like…

<strong>Overload —</strong> Too much information! To cope with all the messages received daily, hourly, minute...<em>ly </em>(?), people only pay attention to the messages that impact them directly and ignore the rest.

<strong>Complexity — </strong>The nature of language itself and the way it’s sometimes used can lead to misunderstandings. We have to keep in mind: Words don’t always carry precisely the same meaning in the mind of our audiences as in ours.

<strong>Noise —</strong> Anything that interferes with the reception of our message. Sometimes a literal barrier (audience never gets the memo, letter, email); sometimes an emotional, cultural or psychological barrier (the person’s background, viewpoint or attitude differ significantly from ours).

<strong>So what can you do?</strong>

If you learn nothing else from us, remember these three things: pyramid, KISS and shoes.

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb3.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-338" title="Pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/pyramid_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb3.jpg?w=300" alt="" width="157" height="107" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/06/13/look-to-the-pyramid-for-the-point/">Get to the point right away and speak directly to your audience.</a>

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/kiss_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb4.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-352" title="Kiss_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/kiss_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb4.jpg" alt="" width="109" height="119" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/03/27/its-all-in-the-k-i-s-s/">Keep it short and simple.</a>

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/tennis-shoe_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb.jpg"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-342" title="Tennis Shoe_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/06/tennis-shoe_sized_cropped_150dpi_rgb.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="112" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/05/09/get-out-of-your-head-and-into-my-shoes/">Get out of your head and into their shoes — think from the audience’s point of view.</a>

Communications are only successful if your audience understands and reacts in the way that achieves your <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/06/01/four-months-til-it-all-breaks-loose/">objective.</a> Pay attention to your audiences’ action, or lack thereof, and adjust your communications accordingly. Uncover the barriers that are impeding your communications and overcome the hurdles.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Justices May Run — But You Can’t.</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/the-justices-may-run-but-you-cant/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Jun 2012 17:40:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=357</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On Thursday, we will be witnessing one of the most important rulings in the history of benefit plans. And no matter which way the Supreme Court rules on the constitutionality of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, there will be major implications to the health care industry — and a great deal of work for HR staffs around the country.

As the justices scurry out of town, you’ll be told to either:
<ul>
	<li>Hightail it into gear to comply with the Act, or</li>
	<li>Find time and energy in an already exhaustive schedule to figure out which rules (if any) need reversing that you hurriedly put into place last year.</li>
</ul>
<strong>So where do you start? </strong>First and foremost — talk to your employees. They will see and hear the news reports and most definitely start asking questions. <em>“Do I have to remove my adult child from my insurance?” “Are you still going to cover my routine physical next week?” </em>And so on.

The best thing you can do right now…while waiting with bated breath…is prepare a statement or various statements for all possible outcomes. You don’t have to know all the answers or any answers — just be honest.

If you aren’t sure how the ruling affects your company’s benefits, tell employees that. But reassure them that you are doing the necessary research to make decisions. If you know how the ruling will affect your benefits, but need time to prepare a proper communication, tell employees that, too.

The important thing to do after Thursday is acknowledge to employees that you know they have questions and that you are on top of getting them answers.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Are You Really Talking About Health, or Just Your Plans?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/are-you-really-talking-about-health-or-just-your-plans/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jul 2012 13:44:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=365</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

I recently spoke at the International Foundation of Employee Benefit Plans (IFEBP) regional conference on Communications and Technology. It was a great conference with lots of interesting ideas and people. A comment was made by one of the speakers that really struck me. We spend a lot of time and effort to communicate to employees about health care. But how much of that effort is devoted to plan basics versus basic steps they can take to improve their health? After all, isn’t that the real goal?

To that end, I’d like to provide you with a couple of great resources for information and materials you can use, free of charge. (Yes, I said free!). Even better, these materials are prepared by professional, unbiased organizations.

<strong>Questions Are the Answer
</strong><a href="http://www.ahrq.gov/questions">This campaign</a> was created by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, part of the U.S. Dept. of Health &amp; Human Services. It is loaded with videos, brochures, and flyers, encouraging folks to ask questions and get involved in their care. There’s even a plain-English glossary to translate doctor-speak into everyday language. Plus, an interactive question builder tool to help patients put together the right questions, based on their situation.

<strong>Choosing Wisely
</strong><a href="http://choosingwisely.org/?page_id=13">Choosing Wisely</a> is a campaign sponsored by the ABIM Foundation. Nine leading medical societies developed lists of <em>Five Things Physicians and Patients Should Question</em> that will “encourage conversations between physicians and patients to improve care and eliminate unnecessary tests and procedures.” The lists cover allergy and asthma, cardiology, radiology, oncology, family physician visits and more.

<strong>Consumer Reports
</strong>The Choosing Wisely campaign is also supported on the Consumer Reports <span style="text-decoration:underline;"><a href="http://consumerhealthchoices.org/campaigns/choosing-wisely/">health site</a>.
</span>

They have summarized and simplified the information even further. You can access flyers and videos on topics, such as:
<ul>
	<li>When do you need antibiotics for sinusitis?</li>
	<li>When do you need imaging tests for lower back pain?</li>
	<li>Bone-density tests: When you need them and when you don’t.</li>
	<li>How should you treat heartburn and GERD?</li>
</ul>
We want employees to be healthier. We want them to be smart consumers of health care. But it’s not an easy transition. By providing the right tools, maybe we can help folks take the first step.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>TMI? How to Organize Wellness Info to Make it Useful</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/tmi-how-to-organize-wellness-info-to-make-it-useful/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Jul 2012 14:34:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=380</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

In last week’s <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/07/03/are-you-really-talking-about-health-or-just-your-plans/">blog</a>, I featured three great websites that you can use to encourage employees to become more engaged in their health care.
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.ahrq.gov/questions"><strong>Questions are the Answer</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://choosingwisely.org/?page_id=13"><strong>Choosing Wisely</strong></a></li>
	<li><a href="http://consumerhealthchoices.org/campaigns/choosing-wisely/"><strong>Consumer Reports’ Choosing Wisely</strong></a></li>
</ul>
Each site has a great deal of information and free materials that you can use to supplement your wellness communications. In fact, it’s almost overwhelming. That’s why I participated in a webinar for the <a href="https://www.hacohio.org/">Health Action Council of Ohio</a> last week…to help employers understand how they can narrow down and utilize the information in a meaningful way.

The following are a few of the tips I provided:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Look at your claims data</strong>. Which disease states or conditions are the biggest issues for your participants? Is it diabetes? Allergy and asthma? Osteoarthritis? Gastrointestinal? Pick a couple of your top issues to focus on first.</li>
	<li><strong>Develop a plan</strong>. As someone who’s followed our blog, you understand the importance of planning. Assuming you have an annual communications plan, review your plan to see how you can incorporate the materials from these websites into your scheduled wellness campaigns. For example, were you already planning to do a diabetes campaign? Utilize the diabetes-related questions, videos and tools from these sites into your communication mix.</li>
	<li><strong>Dedicate a portion of your website to a practical toolkit</strong>. You can’t just “push” information. You also need to have a well-publicized, clearly organized portion of your website for participants to “pull” information when they need it.</li>
</ul>
Think about dedicating a portion of your website to practical tools participants can use in their everyday life. Organize the links and information by disease state or condition. For example, for osteoarthritis, provide direct links to applicable information from the sites above as well as tools or information from your medical provider, wellness vendor and so forth. In this way, participants can easily find the information that specifically applies to them…rather than trying to sort through a lot of material on the web.

If you don’t want to organize your site by specific conditions, at least create an overview section that emphasizes the importance of asking questions and choosing wisely. All three sites provide great information, including flyers, checklists, videos and interactive tools.
<em>Note: you’ll need to monitor your links periodically to ensure they have not changed.</em>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Go beyond links to get the word out. </strong>Providing links is great, but they won’t do any good if participants don’t know about them. Build awareness throughout the year using a variety of vehicles: newsletter articles, teasers in materials, email blasts, posters, table tents, management forums, even postcards to the home (if the site is outside your firewall). <strong></strong></li>
</ul>
They say “knowledge is power,” but too much information can cause inertia. Help your participants by organizing specific wellness information and tools into an easy-to-find-and-navigate web page, then promote that page consistently throughout the year.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Pre-enrollment Communications…Good Idea or Bad?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/pre-enrollment-communicationsgood-idea-or-bad/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Jul 2012 18:15:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=391</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

In general, it’s not a good idea to communicate something to your employees until they can actually take action. Why tell folks about something they have to do, when they can’t do it until a few weeks from now?  But as with all rules, there are exceptions. 

Take annual enrollment. If you are introducing a totally new plan next year, you shouldn’t wait until decision time to start the education process. For example, one of our clients is transitioning to high-deductible HSA plans. The new plans won’t be a total replacement this year, but will be by 2015.

To prepare their employees, we are distributing information through a four-part pre-enrollment series:
<ol>
	<li>New plans are coming</li>
	<li>How the new plans work and compare to your current plans</li>
	<li>The company’s long-term strategy for healthcare – till 2015</li>
	<li>How to prepare for annual enrollment</li>
</ol>
Breaking the information into four parts keeps each communication piece focused and simple to understand. It also helps to build momentum as the campaign ramps up to annual enrollment. 

The goal is to educate employees <em>before</em> they have to make a decision. As our client said, “We want them to be able to have the conversation with their spouse prior to receiving their final enrollment packet. That way, they can figure out their questions and bring them to the meetings to get answered.”

Which brings me to the final point. Pre-enrollment communications isn’t just for employees. We are also educating their HR team so they understand how the new plans work and can answer questions accurately. Providing comprehensive Q&amp;A’s and talking points will help to ensure everyone across the organization is delivering the same message. And that’s a good idea, right?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Where’s Your Summary of Benefits and Coverage Coming From?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/wheres-your-summary-of-benefits-and-coverage-coming-from/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Apr 2012 01:43:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=258</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><strong>From the desk of the resident benefit geek: Kelly O’Connor</strong></em>

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (also known as “health care reform”) requires employers to provide a Summary of Benefits and Coverage. The final regulations require the summary to be delivered by the first day of the plan year following September 23, 2012. Which means most plans must have the summary ready and distributed by January 1, 2013.

<strong>Tip:</strong> Consider including the summary in your annual enrollment materials – you’ll save on postage by including it with the materials you’re already mailing. Plus, it’s the one time a year that employees consider their benefits.

In addition, the regulations say that the summary must “use terminology that is understandable by the average plan enrollee.”

<strong>Tip:</strong> <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/02/07/health-care-is-not-our-native-language/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Write it the way you’d say it</span></a>.

Finally, the summary may be on your radar but we also know that HR departments are waiting to see if their medical plan will provide the summary. And they may. But what if they don’t? Are you considering how you’ll meet this requirement?

<strong>Tip:</strong> The government has provided a template. You can download the summary at <a href="http://www.dol.gov/ebsa/pdf/SBCtemplate.pdf">http://www.dol.gov/ebsa/pdf/SBCtemplate.pdf</a>. Plus, there is a Word version you can download.

P.S.: Don’t fall in love with your summary of benefits. The government is expected to provide revised templates in 2014.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The 95% Factor</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/the-95-factor/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jul 2012 14:03:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=395</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

Back in the late 70’s, my first boss at an ad agency used to refer to the “95% Factor,” meaning that 95% of the time when you are communicating with people, they are only thinking of how the information will impact them. Today, folks refer to it as WIIFM or “what’s in it for me.”

Makes sense. You’re probably thinking that same question right now.

<strong><em>So here’s my HR communication tip for the week: use the 95% Factor to get results by doing the following:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Use the second person, not third.</strong> Don’t speak from the company’s perspective; take the employee’s point of view. Talk about how “you” can access and use your benefits or how “your” performance impacts your pay.</li>
	<li><strong>Be specific. </strong>Focus your communications more on the “what” and “how” and not so much on the “why.” The more specific you are about the actions you want employees to take, the better results you’ll get. It also helps if you can target your communications to specific audiences so folks only get the messages that apply to them. (The last thing you want to do is make people work to figure it out.) Plus, if you can be specific about the personal impact to employees, they will pay closer attention. For example, instead of saying “you can save thousands by switching to this plan,” create versions based on current plan enrollment to say “what would you do with an extra $2,050?”. Believe me, the second version will get more attention.</li>
	<li><strong>Keep it simple.</strong>  Not only should you write from the employee’s point of view, you should speak their language. Avoid acronyms and other benefits “geek speak.” Try to write on about a 5<sup>th</sup> to 7<sup>th</sup> grade level by keeping sentences short and avoiding words with multiple syllables. Not because your audience isn’t smart enough to understand higher reading levels, but because they only have seconds to scan for the 95% Factor information.</li>
	<li><strong>Make it relatable.</strong> People make decisions based on emotions, then justify with facts. To make an emotional connection, your communications need to be relatable. Use photos or images of folks like your employees. If they are blue collar, don’t use the infamous conference room shot of a bunch of models in slick suits. Show folks who get their hands dirty. When you are trying to explain a complex issue, use examples or stories to illustrate your point. People relate much better to stories of “people like me” than they do to charts.</li>
</ul>
When creating your HR communications, keep this in mind: whenever employees see or hear any message, all they want to know is three things:
<ol>
	<li>What’s this about?</li>
	<li>How’s it impact me?</li>
	<li>What do I have to do?</li>
</ol>
Answer those questions, and you’ll have met the 95% Factor 100% of the time.

<em>Note to <span style="text-decoration:underline;">AP Stylebook</span> geeks: I realize percent is supposed to be spelled out. I used the symbol on purpose. </em>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-95-factor</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="human-resource-communication"><![CDATA[human resource communication]]></category>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Being a Smart Health Care Consumer Ain’t Easy!</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/being-a-smart-health-care-consumer-aint-easy/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Aug 2012 19:52:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=401</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

Yesterday, we found out one of our WOT sons has a torn ACL. Ouch! The doctor wanted him to get an MRI right away and set up an appointment at a local facility. Since we have a high deductible plan, the MRI costs $1,000 out of pocket. Wowsers!  I pointed out to his mom that she could probably get the MRI cheaper at another place, but she felt she had to follow the doctor’s orders. After all, her son is in pain, he may need surgery and she wants to get everything handled ASAP before school starts up again.

I tell you this story to make a point: being a “smart health care consumer” sounds good on paper, but it ain’t easy.  

As a caring HR professional, what can you do to help guide your employees? Be open and honest. Tell them it takes effort to do the research but it’s worth it because it will save them money. Then do your own research to identify the best tools they can use and point them in the right direction.  

<strong>During annual enrollment</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Open employees’ eyes to the fact that not all providers cost the same. In fact, costs can be dramatically different among providers, even though the quality is the same.</li>
	<li>Make sure employees understand the cost they pay under a copay plan is much lower than the “real” retail cost.</li>
	<li>Strongly encourage the use of “health plan comparison” or “run your own scenario” tools.</li>
	<li>If employees are moving from a copay plan to a high deductible plan that requires them to pay the full retail cost:
<ul>
	<li>Provide direct links to your prescription administrator’s site where they can find average retail costs; or</li>
	<li>Tell them to take their list of monthly prescriptions to their local pharmacy and ask for the current retail cost. (Prescription out-of-pocket costs are usually the biggest shock to new enrollees in high deductible plans.)</li>
	<li>If available, provide links to health plan service/procedure estimators; or</li>
	<li>Suggest they reach out to their caregivers to determine the full retail cost for services.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
 <strong>After annual enrollment</strong>

Continue to educate throughout the year on topics such as <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/07/03/are-you-really-talking-about-health-or-just-your-plans/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">the importance of asking questions</span></a>, using generics versus brand-name drugs, taking advantage of provider selection tools on your health care administrator’s website, choosing urgent care versus emergency room care and so on. Be sure to use a variety of communication vehicles such as newsletter articles, blog postings, brown bag meetings, Q&amp;A forums or one-on-one coaching sessions. 

The better people understand how to access and use their plan, the more positive they will be about the plan.  They may not become smart health care consumers overnight…but knowing where to go to get reliable information is a good first step.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>When The Going Gets Tough, The Tough Eat Chocolate</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/when-the-going-gets-tough-the-tough-eat-chocolate/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Aug 2012 21:35:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=407</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

Ok, chocolate may not be the healthiest solution to handling stress. But hey, it’s annual enrollment time and thanks to our great clients, we are super busy.  Changes keep coming in, new versions are being added and deadlines refuse to budge. What’s a girl to do?

I’m sure many of you are super busy as well, so I wanted to share some of the tactics we take here at Write on Target (WOT) to handle stress:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Laugh it off</strong>: The best antidote to stress is a good belly laugh. It increases oxygen in the blood, decreases blood sugar and even burns up calories. Seriously. <a href="http://women.webmd.com/guide/give-your-body-boost-with-laughter"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Look it up</span></a>. At WOT, we have a Laugh Board in the middle of our busiest hub where everyone jots down something that made them laugh that day.  It helps to spread the joy.</li>
	<li><strong>Get on the ball: </strong>We each have large exercise balls that we use in exchange for our regular desk chairs once in a while. It’s a great way to stretch out the back. It also enables a certain artist to bounce around a bit when her nervous energy builds up. <em>Warning: excessive bouncing by one employee may make your pregnant employee sick to her stomach. </em></li>
	<li><strong>Stretch yourself:</strong> Did you know if you sit all day at work you literally lose years off your life? Take time to stretch at least every couple of hours. These <a href="http://www.yogajournal.com/practice/231"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">six stretches</span></a> will give you a good start. You can also download apps to remind you to move, including one created by our pal, Fran Melmed called <a href="http://www.freerangecomm.com/2012/05/5-tools-help-employees-avoid-sitting-disease/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Hotseat</span></a>.</li>
	<li><strong>Take a hike:</strong> If you can find a minute or two, get out of the office for a short walk. If you’re really nice, you might even bring back a treat for your coworkers. (hint, hint)</li>
	<li><strong>Get silly:</strong> One of our favorite stress relievers is Silly Putty. Each of us has several containers stashed at our desk to stretch, knead and throw at each other.</li>
</ul>
How do you handle stress? I’d love to hear your creative ideas. Drop me a note at <a href="mailto:eborton@writetarget.com">eborton@writetarget.com</a> and I’ll share with others. In the meantime, I think I’ll have a piece of chocolate.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Check Your Numbers</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/check-your-numbers/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 15:25:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=412</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

Anyone who knows me, knows that numbers are not my friend. I once freaked out over a restaurant bill that I thought was $900 when it was really $90. (What’s another zero among friends?)

So I guess it makes sense that I give you this word of warning as you prepare your annual enrollment materials: triple-check your numbers. Making a mistake in your math or transposing a digit in a phone number not only results in misinformation, but embarrassment and possibly the added cost of reprinting. Checking numbers seems so simple, but in our haste, even the best of us have forgone that step.
<ul>
	<li><strong>Charts or Examples: </strong>Be careful when picking up a chart or example from a previous communication. Make sure all figures are updated to match the upcoming year. Mistakes can also occur when an example is edited through multiple versions of materials. Before you go to print or post the final piece, ask someone new to review the figures to make sure they are correct.</li>
	<li><strong>Automated comparison tools</strong>: If you have an automated plan comparison tool, make sure you update all the numbers used to make the calculations. Have you updated the employee premiums for 2013? Did you reduce the health care flexible spending account limit to $2,500? Did your Health Savings Account limits increase? How about company contributions? Once all the input numbers are corrected, run scenarios for every plan and every level of coverage to make sure it all adds up.</li>
	<li><strong>Contacts: </strong>If you provide a list of contacts, check every URL and call every number to make sure it is accurate. Hint: if you hear heavy breathing on the other end of a toll-free number, you probably need to make a correction.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Devil Is In The Details Of Your Summary Of Benefits Coverage Docs</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/the-devil-is-in-the-details-of-your-summary-of-benefits-coverage-docs/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Sep 2012 15:35:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=419</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

In my last blog, I talked about the importance of <a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/08/22/check-your-numbers/"><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">checking and rechecking any numbers</span></strong></a> in your communications for accuracy. The same goes for the new Summary of Benefits Coverage (SBC’s) documents that employers are required to distribute starting September 23 to meet the Accountable Care Act (also known as Health Care Reform).

At first glance, the SBC’s seem like an easy task to check off your to-do list. Most health care vendors are filling in the government-designed templates for their clients. All you have to do is hang them on your site or mail to employees. Easy, right?

Well, not so fast.

Since we create and maintain Summary Plan Descriptions for our clients, many have asked us to review the SBC documents sent to them by their vendors. We have found some vendors are providing base documents, but are not including the specific nuances designed into the plans.

<strong><em>When you get your SBC’s, closely check some of the following areas:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Penalties:</strong> If you have penalty fees, e.g. for not pre-certifying a hospital stay, the fees need to be in the Limits and Exceptions box on the same line where the coverage is listed.</li>
	<li><strong>Limitations</strong>: If your plan has unique limitation amounts, e.g. for speech and physical therapy or home health and hospice service, make sure they are listed correctly, again on the same line where the coverage is listed.</li>
	<li><strong>Prescription carve outs</strong>: If your prescription coverage is carved out from your medical plan, your medical vendor probably won’t complete that section. You will need to complete that part of the template and ask your prescription vendor to review it for accuracy.</li>
</ul>
For the initial year, the Department of Labor has indicated it wants to work with plans to get to compliance and is not focusing on imposing penalties. Therefore, you might not be concerned about meeting every regulation spelled out in the government’s 15-page instructions. However, keep in mind that you will probably pick up the same document next year, so it would probably be worth the time and effort to get it as accurate and complete as possible. As is true with most benefits and HR communications, the devil is in the details.]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Employees Hold The Remote — So Use Multiple Channels</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/employees-hold-the-remote-so-use-multiple-channels/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Sep 2012 21:16:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=425</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

As you prepare your annual enrollment materials, how many communication channels are you planning to use? A recent study conducted by the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America shows that you better use more than one. Guardian’s study, <a href="http://www.aboutemployeebenefits.com/reports/Research-Reports-Benefits-and-Behavior.html"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Benefits &amp; Behavior: Spotlight on the Benefits of an Employee-Centric Enrollment Experience</span></a> found the following:
<ul>
	<li>70 percent of employees who could receive enrollment information in their preferred channel said they were confident in their benefit selections versus 57 percent of those who did not.</li>
	<li>Workers want to receive benefits communications through multiple channels. In fact, 20 percent would like six or more options.</li>
	<li>80 percent seek the ease and convenience of online enrollment so they can enroll where and when they choose. 9 in 10 workers who enrolled online were very satisfied with the experience.</li>
	<li>Employees who could get information and enroll through the channel they prefer are more likely to make more informed enrollment decisions, have a higher perceived value of their benefits and ultimately feel more satisfied with their benefits.</li>
	<li> Benefits satisfaction leads to greater loyalty and retention.</li>
</ul>
<strong>What can you do?</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Use multiple channels to deliver your enrollment messages (e.g. online, email, text messages, manager speaking points, electronic message boards, video, group meetings, posters, home mailings, webinars, apps and social media). You have a lot of options at your fingertips. Think outside the box and get creative. Be sure to include channels that will reach the spouse, a key decision maker during enrollment.</li>
	<li>Make sure your enrollment messaging is clear, concise and consistent across all channels. Stick with three key points that you want to get across and hit them in every communication.</li>
	<li>If you do not have a benefits site on the internet, create one so the information is accessible by computer, smartphones or tablets. We’ve designed sites that house the annual enrollment information as well as a customized plan comparison tool. Once employees are prepared, they simply click on a link to take them to the enrollment transaction site. The benefits site is then updated and used throughout the year for new hires.</li>
	<li>Ask your employees which channels they prefer. You can add this question to your post-enrollment surveys.</li>
</ul>
Sadly, the Guardian study found that 63 percent of employers think their benefit communications are ineffective and 6 in 10 workers agree. What would your employees say? Remember, you may be the employer, but employees hold the remote in today’s multimedia world. Use multiple channels and your messages will get through.

<strong> </strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Most Overlooked Communication Channel</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/the-most-overlooked-communication-channel/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 20:23:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=432</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

In the last blog, I talked about using multiple communication channels for all your benefits and HR initiatives. You can’t just tell your story once and be done. People need to hear a message several times (in fact, closer to seven times) before they really get it.

As you develop your communications plan, don’t forget the most overlooked communications channel…your company’s middle managers. They are a frontline resource that can make or break your communications campaign. Think about it. Managers typically talk to employees at least once a week, if not every day. If they are well informed and receive the right tools they can not only spread your message, they can positively influence how employees react. Unfortunately, the opposite is also true. The last thing you want is to have managers dismiss a new HR initiative as “another crazy idea from corporate.”

To promote manager support, think about providing the following materials for any major initiative or rollout.

<strong><em>Typical communications toolkit for managers:</em></strong>

Deliver these tools through normal business updates to managers or post online if you have a secured “manager toolkit” section on your Intranet.
<ul>
	<li><strong>Talking points</strong>. Stick to the three main things you want employees to know. (e.g. What’s changing, what do I need to do, when is the deadline) Managers don’t need to know all the details, but they should know the key points and where to direct employees for more information.</li>
	<li><strong>Frequently asked questions</strong>: FAQs are a good tool for managers to have on hand to understand an initiative and possible issues that may arise.</li>
	<li><strong>Template materials and messaging</strong>: If applicable, provide managers with the materials they need to spread the message through local resources.</li>
	<li><strong>Communications training</strong>: Encourage your organization to spend a larger portion of their training dollars and resources to help managers become better communicators. It’s an investment that will pay off for the company as well as the managers themselves. </li>
</ul>
<strong>Additional tips</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Inform managers first</strong>. Give managers time to review the materials you’ll be sending to employees as well as the talking points or tools. They can then ask questions about any issues unique to their team and plan how they will react when their team hears important news.</li>
	<li><strong>Encourage managers to share ideas</strong>. If you are rolling out a large, company-wide initiative, encourage managers to share ideas with one another through online collaboration tools. An approach that works in one location will probably work well in another.</li>
	<li><strong>Use surveys to see if messages are cascaded correctly</strong>. Survey employees after the rollout to see if key messages were received and understood.  If misunderstandings are centralized in one area, you might have a communication “block” to unplug.</li>
	<li><strong>Make employee communications and engagement part of managers’ goals and measure success</strong>. Managers should be held accountable for their communication skills. Ideally, it should be a key component of their annual goals and supported by 360<sup>◦ </sup>feedback from their direct reports.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Set Navigational Buoys In Your Communications</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/set-navigational-buoys-in-your-communications/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Oct 2012 20:46:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=439</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

This weekend, my husband and I will be taking off the sails and preparing our sailboat for haul out for the winter. As the summer draws to a close and fall begins, I thought it might be a good time for another installment of “How Living On a Boat Made Me a Better HR Communicator.” In January, I discussed how "<a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/01/24/living-on-a-boat-hr-communications/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">less is more</span></a>,” then covered the “<a href="http://writetargetblog.com/2012/04/10/cruising-and-writing-tip-2-get-to-know-the-locals/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">importance of getting to know the locals</span></a>” in April. Today, I’d like to explore the value of navigational buoys.

Navigational buoys are like road signs to sailors. They help seafarers to stay in channels, avoid dangers like shallow reefs and stay on course to arrive safely at their destination. The same principles can be applied to the design of your HR communications.

<strong>Help employees to navigate through your materials</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Don’t crowd the page</strong>: If your communications are jammed packed with information, employees will give up before they even start. Keep information in bite-sized pieces, with plenty of white space between sections.</li>
	<li><strong>Use colors and design to guide the eye</strong>: Good design is usually fairly simple yet brilliant because it effortlessly guides an employee’s eye through the piece or website. When you scan a piece, does your eye go to the most important information? Do the graphic illustrations communicate the main point you want to get across in a glance?</li>
	<li><strong>Use subheads to quickly tell the story</strong>: An employee should be able to only read the subheads throughout your piece and get the following questions answered: “What’s this about? How’s it impact me? What do I have to do?”</li>
	<li><strong>Use relatable photos</strong>: If you use photos in your piece, make sure they match the demographics of your target audience. If most of your employees are blue collar workers, don’t use the popular conference room meeting shots.</li>
	<li><strong>Use cover sheets if you have multiple inserts: </strong>If you are giving employees a packet with multiple inserts (such as a new hire kit) use a cover sheet as a navigational buoy. List each of the inserts, what they are about and what an employee needs to do with each. It will help them to sort through the materials more quickly and understand the actions they need to take.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Social Psychology Tips To Engage And Motivate</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/social-psychology-tips-to-engage-and-motivate/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Oct 2012 15:46:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=443</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></b>

Last week, Paul Hebert spoke at the Greater Cincinnati HR Association meeting. I first met Paul at <a href="http://thehrevolution.org/">HRevolution</a> and then was captivated by his presentation at the Ohio SHRM in 2011. As the Managing Director and lead consultant for <a href="http://www.i2i-align.com/">I2I</a>, his is widely considered an expert on what it takes to engage and motivate people. Specifically, he talks about social elements that impact behavior as well as the way in which the human brain processes requests and makes decisions.

The use of social psychology techniques in communications is nothing new. Advertising and marketing folks have used these techniques since the first billboards were created in caves (ok, I might be exaggerating a bit). I’m sharing Paul’s tips this week so you can think how you might apply them to your communications.

<b>Elements of social psychology </b>
<ul>
	<li><b><i>Reciprocity</i></b>: People tend to want to comply with a request if they’ve already received a favor.</li>
	<li><b><i>Commitment and consistency</i></b>: People like to remain consistent with past behaviors and commitments.</li>
	<li><b><i>Social proof and consistency</i></b>: People tend to follow the behavior they see in others.</li>
	<li><b><i>Authority</i></b>: People unconsciously follow advice from perceived authority figures.</li>
	<li><b><i>Because</i></b><b>:</b> People subconsciously respond to requests when the word “because” is included. Always provide a reason for the request.</li>
</ul>
<b>How could you apply these techniques?</b>
<ul>
	<li><b>Consumer driven plans</b>: Get employees to share stories about how they saved money by researching and comparison shopping for services (Social proof). Include stories from doctors who are not threatened by patients who ask questions and are involved in their care, but rather, encourage patients to do so. (Authority).</li>
	<li> <b>Wellness initiatives</b>: If you are going to ask employees to compete in a fitness challenge, take a poll prior to the campaign to ask them which activities they’d like to participate in and get them to affirm they’ll participate. (Commitment).  Give regular updates of how teams are performing throughout the campaign (Consistency).</li>
	<li> <b>Retention:</b> Use a variety of testimonials from employees about how they have benefited from the benefits and services the company provides (Social proof).</li>
	<li><b> </b><b>Training</b>: To encourage more participation in training programs, focus on the number of people who are taking the training, rather than the opposite (Social proof). Be specific about how the training could improve employees’ careers (Because factor).</li>
</ul>
<b><i>Do you have applicable success stories you’d like to share? Please post in comments.</i></b>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Salaried And Union Hourly Employees Are Not The Same</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/salaried-and-union-hourly-employees-are-not-the-same/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Oct 2012 20:45:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=452</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></b>

Ok, I’m not trying to be politically incorrect. I just want to point out the pitfalls that can occur when you need to communicate different messages to salaried employees versus union hourly.

<b><i>Example from Annual Enrollment</i></b>
<ul>
	<li><b>Salaried employees</b> are losing their current medical plans and must elect from new options. If they do not enroll, they will have no coverage.</li>
	<li><b>Union hourly employees</b> are keeping the same medical plans. They do not need to actively enroll unless they want to participate in the Flexible Spending Account.</li>
</ul>
You may think you have this communication challenge covered by creating separate, targeted communications that clearly outline what’s changing (or not changing) for the group and the steps they need to take. In your mind, you have them neatly separated into two groups.

But alas, life is not that tidy.

Humans are social by nature. They talk. They overhear things. And doggone it, they don’t read everything you give them, even if your text is clear as a bell. So confusion starts to rear its ugly head. The union employees don’t want to risk not having coverage. They ask their manager (who is salaried) and he/she tells them “yes, your plan is going away so you must enroll.”  Or, since some union employees are married to salaried employees, two different communications arrive in the mail and they get confused as to what they need to do.

<b><i>What’s a conscientious HR communicator to do? </i></b>
<ul>
	<li>Provide HR and management with a clear outline of the various groups in their population, the key changes for the groups and what the employees need to do. In this way, when questions arise, they can provide proper advice.</li>
	<li>Keep the rumor mill in mind by addressing head-on what may be overheard.
<ul>
	<li>For example, create a sidebar with copy such as “you may have heard that salaried employees need to choose a new medical plan for 2013. This is not the case for you, since your medical plans will remain the same for 2013, as outlined in your bargaining agreement.”</li>
	<li>Include a sidebar in your main communications to address those employees who are married and have different benefit options. Clearly outline what they need to do.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Produce Questions and Answer sheets that directly address any misconceptions that begin to crop up. Rumors are best nipped in the bud.</li>
</ul>
Bottom line…you’ll never avoid questions and some confusion when you have different benefits for different groups. But the more clear and direct you can be in your communications, the better.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Shut Up And Vote!</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/shut-up-and-vote/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Nov 2012 13:24:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=459</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></b>

I live in Ohio. That means I’ve been inundated with ads, phone calls, post cards and flyers.

Finally…today is E-Day.

So it’s time to shut up and VOTE!

It’s not just your right and your privilege…it’s your responsibility.

<a href="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/vote2.png"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-471" title="vote" alt="" src="http://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2012/11/vote2.png?w=283" height="369" width="417" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>To Tell A Good Story, Listen First</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/to-tell-a-good-story-listen-first/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Nov 2012 19:25:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=480</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></b>

This Friday, November 23, is the National Day of Listening, a national holiday started by StoryCorps in 2008. <a href="http://storycorps.org/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">StoryCorps </span></a>is a nonprofit organization that encourages everyday folks to record, share and preserve the stories of their lives. Since 2003, they have collected and archived more than 40,000 interviews that are preserved at the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress.

I discovered the StoryCorps interviews on <a href="http://www.billbradley.com/american-voices/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">American Voices</span></a>, Senator Bill Bradley’s show on Sirius/XM. The stories are so unique and so touching because they are <span style="text-decoration:underline;">real</span> stories about <span style="text-decoration:underline;">real</span> folks.

Storytelling is a popular buzzword in communications these days, but it’s been a powerful tool since the beginning of time. You can tap into the power of storytelling in your HR and Benefits communications as well. Let your employees tell the story about how they have used a benefit, or improved their health, or saved money by shopping for healthcare services. Believe me, it will have much more impact than any copy you could create.

But, as my headline says, to tell a good story, you need to listen first. Reach out to your population to ask about their experiences. Think about running a contest to find some great success stories. If you have HR reps in remote locations, ask them to hook you up with employees who have benefited from the company’s programs or services.

To practice your listening skills, join in the StoryCorps’ National Day of Listening. Take a few minutes to <a href="http://storycorps.org/listen/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">listen to some examples</span></a>, then record an interview with a loved one. You can use the recording device on your smartphone, computer or a tape recorder. The <a href="http://nationaldayoflistening.org/participate/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Do-It-Yourself Guide</span></a> on the StoryCorps website provides everything you need, including a list of sample questions.

Enjoy your holiday…and uncover some great stories!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Installing New Software In The Coming Year? Better Plan Your Communications Now!</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/installing-new-software-in-the-coming-year-better-plan-your-communications-now/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 29 Nov 2012 20:41:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=495</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<b><i>By Elizabeth Borton</i></b>

This past August, while attending the Indiana SHRM conference as a speaker, I sat in on a presentation by <a href="http://www.tincup.com/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">William Tincup</span></a>, an irreverent thought leader on user adoption of new technology. Why would a communications consultant wander into his presentation? Two reasons: 1) I’d seen him speak before and I got a kick out of his style (the guy made me laugh); and 2) I wanted to hear how companies are handling communications around software implementation. As William pointed out, “HR software will not be adopted at the employee level without proactive communication.”

Think about it. Companies spend so much time researching software vendors and their products, choosing and tweaking just the right package and then sitting in upteen meetings to ensure a smooth implementation. But does anyone stop to create a communication plan to roll out that new technology? Helloooo? Anyone? (crickets)

William has some very definite thoughts around this subject. He said that rather than using the “shock and awe” approach of shoving new technology in employees’ faces and telling them to use it or else, companies would be better served to create a well-thought-out communication/training/change management strategy. As William puts it, “Explain the reason for changing the software, why it’s important and how it aligns with the corporate mission and values. Tie it back. Don’t say you’re doing it just for the really cool software.” Of course, you’ll want to spotlight senior level support but don’t ignore the power of bringing it down to the “what’s in it for me” level. “Acknowledge it’s a change and change is stressful…but then show them how the software will make their job easier,” suggests William. Another big key to success is to ensure the users’ first experience is a good one. Keep the rollout simple and (here’s a novel idea) fun! Offer incentives for early adopters. “If they have a good experience initially, they will be more apt to work through the kinks in the future without grumbling,” notes William. Finally, as you develop your communication plan, build in opportunities for employees to share success stories. As the positive momentum builds, so too will your user adoption.

So if you get wind that the company is looking at implementing new software in the coming year, raise your hand and ask if someone is developing a communications plan. It could make you a hero. After all, what good is a really cool software package if no one uses it?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Our Story of Who-ville (or Whom-ville)</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/our-story-of-who-ville-or-whom-ville/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Dec 2012 16:28:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=501</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Most everyone
Down in WOT-ville
Liked grammar a lot…

But a few
Who struggled with it
Did NOT!

Now we love all the Whos and the story of thee
But sometimes a Who is used
In a spot where a Whom needs to be.

Oh the horror of misuse
The horror
Indeed! Indeed! Indeed!

Here is a rule
To help you know the difference
Of when to use a Who or a Whom in a sentence.

He = Who
Him = Whom
If He works as the pronoun, you’ll know a Who is correct.
If Him works better, a Whom you should elect.

An example for learning
To know the difference you are yearning

<em><strong>W</strong><b>ho/</b><strong>whom</strong> should I pick?</em>
The sentence fits him because “You would pick him.”
So, into the sentence <b>Whom</b> is what sticks.

<em><strong>Who</strong><b>/Whom</b> wrote the rhyme?</em>
Ahhh… <b>He</b> wrote the rhyme.
So in the sentence you put <b>Who</b> this time.

Now if you’ve followed this rhyme
And learned what’s correct…
Too much time on your hand — what the heck!

Get out there in Who-ville, Green-ville, the like
Get shopping and caroling and enjoying your time.
No grinches in your way of a merry holiday
Is our wish to you and your family

Happy Holidays!]]></content:encoded>
