	<item>
		<title>Win or Lose, Frame Your Headlines To Get More Action</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/win-or-lose-frame-your-headlines-to-get-more-action/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Mar 2014 21:14:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=711</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<i>By Elizabeth Borton</i>

Which headline do you think would get more response
<ol>
	<li><i></i><i>“It’s time to get a mammogram”</i></li>
	<li><i></i><i>“Set a good example for your daughter and get peace of mind. Get a mammogram.”</i></li>
</ol>
The answer is number two. Why? Because it uses “framing” to help your target audience to clearly understand what they would gain by taking action. Framing is a behavioral economics concept that can be used to improve the results of your benefits communications. Headlines can also be framed as a loss. For example, a loss-frame would be, <i>“Are you really going to pass up the $500 Premier Co will give you when you enroll in the high-deductible health plan?”</i> According to an article in <b>Benefits Quarterly</b>,
a publication of the International Society of Certified Employee Benefit Specialists, you can use either gain or loss framing to your advantage. However, certain circumstances work better with one versus the other.

The article states, “Research has shown that gain frames work better in the health and wellness area to drive prevention (e.g. using sunscreen) and treatment (e.g. taking prescribed medication). On the other hand, loss frames seem to work better to motivate detection behaviors (e.g. screening).” In fact, in the mammogram example cited above, research indicates a headline like, <i>“Your family needs you now…and later.
Get a mammogram.”</i> may work even better.

Some employers may shy away from using a loss frame, but when you consider that employees must take more accountability and actions for their health and retirement planning, you might want to consider a two-pronged approach. Use both gain and loss frames for your headlines during your campaign so your target audience can see both the potential gain and loss in a particular situation. If a person isn’t motivated by the gain, the loss just might prompt action.

The article suggests the next time you are writing a headline, consider the following:
<ul>
	<li>What will people gain if they do this — financially, socially, emotionally
or physically?</li>
	<li>What will people lose if they don’t do this?</li>
	<li>Will promoting the gains work better in this situation, with these people, or would highlighting losses work better?</li>
	<li>How should I craft the message to actively suggest or promote either gains
or losses?</li>
</ul>
I have a couple additional tips to add:
<ul>
	<li>Make your headline relatable to your audience.</li>
	<li>Use action verbs.</li>
	<li>Be very clear about the action you want them to take.</li>
</ul>
Try using framing in your next campaign and track the results.  Win or lose, you’ll start to discover which type of headlines get more action.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Download Free Retirement Education Materials</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/download-free-retirement-education-materials/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Apr 2014 18:41:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=721</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>To celebrate National Employee Benefits Day</em></strong>

<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

Every year on April 2, the International Foundation of Employee Benefit Plans (IFEBP) celebrates National Employee Benefits Day by providing free benefits education materials. This year, the focus is on retirement planning.

According to the Employee Benefits Research institute, almost<strong> nine in ten people don’t think they’ll have enough saved when they get to retirement. </strong>That’s a scary proposition. What can you do to help your employees?

Log on to the<a title="Benefits Day" href="http://www.ifebp.org/benefitsday"><strong> IFEBP Benefits Day website</strong></a> to access a variety of helpful
resources including:
<ul>
	<li>Short articles targeting two specific populations: “Picture Your Retirement” for those who are less than 15 years from retirement and “Take Control of Your Future” for those who are more than 15 years from retiring.</li>
	<li>Terminology handouts: to help your employees understand the key terms around retirement plans, investments and credit.</li>
	<li>Interactive budgeting worksheets</li>
	<li>Retirement savings tips</li>
	<li>Retirement security videos</li>
	<li>Helpful government resources</li>
</ul>
<strong>Heck, there’s even a <a title="cat video" href="http://youtu.be/7JDFgSwNOYo">cat video</a></strong>! What more could you need? Make the investment in your employees’ future by using these free materials to help them understand the importance of investing in themselves.

Oh, and by the way, Happy National Employee Benefits Day!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Employees Tend To Follow The Leader</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/employees-tend-to-follow-the-leader/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 Apr 2014 13:18:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=731</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

In a previous blog about behavioral economics, I talked about <a title="using framing in your headlines to get action" href="http://writetargetblog.com/2014/03/21/win-or-lose-frame-your-headlines-to-get-more-action/" target="_blank">using “framing” in your headlines to get action</a>. Today, I’d like to share the second lesson from that same <strong>Benefits Quarterly </strong>article, which states that “people strive to do what is socially expected and acceptable.”

Think of a wave at a football game. It’s contagious. Research has shown that in certain situations, especially when we are uncertain what to do, we follow the lead of others.

How can you apply this principle to your benefits communications?
<ol>
	<li><strong><em><strong><em>Point out specifically what the majority of people are doing right.
</em></strong></em></strong>The following examples use what is known as descriptive norms:
“Last year, over 85% of all PremierCo employees, and over 90% of employees at your location, got a flu shot.”
“Four out of five employees contribute enough to the 401(k) plan to get the Company matching funds.”
Tip: Make the descriptive norm comparison as similar to your target audience as possible (e.g. “people at your location” or “sales associates”). <strong><strong><em><strong><em><strong><em>
</em></strong></em></strong></em></strong></strong></li>
	<li><strong><em><strong><em>Set the social rules for what’s acceptable and what’s not.
</em></strong></em></strong>If you haven’t yet achieved the stats to use descriptive norms, try injunctive norms which describe the behaviors that are and are not approved. Injunctive norms fall under the umbrella of “this is who we are and what we stand for.” Many companies have used this approach for initiatives such as safety, no smoking and no texting or cell phone usage while driving. The <strong>Benefits Quarterly</strong> article also cited a company that transitioned from talking about biometric screenings and health risk assessments as something “you should do” to something that is expected. The article quoted their materials as follows: “We’re passionate about helping our customers on their paths to better health. To succeed, we all need to be on the same path ourselves. Starting now, all employees enrolled in one of our medical plans must get a health screening and complete an online health risk assessment every year. Why? The evidence is clear that these are the right things to do.”</li>
</ol>
<strong><em>A couple tips</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>Avoid using statistics that highlight bad behavior. </em></strong>Consider the following stat: “seven out of ten American adults don’t exercise regularly, despite the proven health benefits” (“CNN,” April 7, 2012). You may think that will get people’s attention, but it may have the opposite effect. Your employees may interpret it as, “I’m ok because most people like me don’t exercise.”  It’s better to focus on stats that reinforce good behavior.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Testimonials pack more punch than stats. </em></strong>There’s nothing like a good story, especially when it’s told by “people like me.” Encourage your employees to share their success stories.  They’ll not only get a pat on the back, they may inspire others to take action.</li>
</ul>
Behavioral economics may be a science, but when you think about it, these tips are pretty much common sense. Put yourself in your employees’ shoes, give them a good example to follow and you’ll do just fine.]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>employees-tend-to-follow-the-leader</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Designating Beneficiaries Is A Year-Round Communications Effort</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/designating-beneficiaries-is-a-year-round-communications-effort-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Apr 2014 15:00:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=741</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

Earlier this month, the Internal Revenue Service issued <a title="Notice 2014-19" href="http://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Treatment-of-Marriages-of-Same-Sex-Couples-for-Retirement-Plan-Purposes">Notice 2014-19</a>, setting
the rules for recognition of same-sex spouses in retirement plan administration.
Non-governmental single employer retirement plans have until Dec. 31 of 2014 to
adopt an amendment recognizing same-sex spouses for the purposes of:
<ul>
	<li>Providing survivor benefits</li>
	<li>Obtaining spousal consent</li>
	<li>Making required minimum distributions</li>
	<li>Accepting qualified domestic relations orders</li>
	<li>Issuing hardship withdrawals</li>
	<li>Carrying out other retirement plan administration functions</li>
</ul>
We discussed the change in our Monday morning meeting since the rules will impact the many summary plan descriptions that we maintain for our clients.

It got me wondering…what percentage of retirement plan participants fill out a beneficiary form? An article on the Society of Human Resources website entitled,<a title="401(k) Auto Enrollment – The Problem of Missing Beneficiary Elections" href="http://www.shrm.org/hrdisciplines/benefits/articles/pages/beneficiary.aspx"> “401(k) Auto Enrollment – The Problem of Missing Beneficiary Elections”</a> indicated that 30-40 percent of participants do not have a beneficiary designation due to missing paper forms or online elections. However, that rate is growing due to auto enrollments. The article notes, “Participants who are auto enrolled have no beneficiary designation, given that it is not possible to ‘auto elect’ a beneficiary.” Record keepers say they will follow up with participants to get beneficiaries, but the real responsibility lies with the plan sponsor. You can read the article for more details.

In the meantime, have you checked to see how many of your plan participants are missing a beneficiary designation? Are their designations up to date? (After all, the divorce rate is 40-50 percent.) Did you know that if remarried employees designate their children from a previous marriage, they still have to get a spousal waiver from their second spouse?

Educating participants about the importance of beneficiary designations
is an important year-round topic. Make it part of your ongoing benefits
communications plan.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>741</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	<item>
		<title>Engaging Employees With Online Tools</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/engaging-employees-with-online-tools/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 27 May 2014 14:32:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=750</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

Having been in the benefits communications industry for over 20 years, I’ve seen trends come and go. But I have never seen the level of responsibility that is being asked of employees today. Those who have been passive or downright apathetic in the past are now being asked to become “smart shoppers” of healthcare. That’s a 180 from the days of following doctor’s orders and depending on insurance to foot the bill. Today, we want employees to be smart consumers who shop for healthcare like they shop for cars. Problem is, there’s no “Blue Book” on healthcare treatments. No Consumer Reports. However, as with all voids in the marketplace, some really good solutions have popped up. The following are some outstanding online services that are getting results for employers because they deliver on two counts:
<ol>
	<li>They are engaging, so they entice employees to try them out. <em>(You’ll get nowhere without meeting this criteria.)</em></li>
	<li>They provide valuable, real-time information that can help employees to make smart, informed decisions.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Jellyvision</strong>: As a developer of interactive online programs and games, Jellyvision released “Alex”, a virtual benefits counselor in 2009. I think most people in our business have at least seen a demo of Alex in action. He uses a friendly and easy-to-understand style to lead employees through a series of simple questions to help them determine which health plan is the best fit for their situation. He can also help employees
through status changes that impact their benefits. You can <a title="Jellyvision" href="http://www.jellyvision.com/" target="_blank">meet Alex</a> through
Jellyvision’s demo.

<strong>Castlight Health</strong>: Launched in 2008, the cloud-based healthcare management system offers cost comparison tools for elective procedures, high-cost diagnostic tests, specialists, hospitals and other types of care. They also recently launched a pharmacy app to help folks to shop for the best prices on medication. Visit their <a title="Castlight Health" href="http://www.castlighthealth.com/" target="_blank">website</a> to
learn more.

<strong>Change Healthcare</strong>: This online system allows employees to search for a prescription or medical, dental or vision service based on their health plan, network or location. It provides cost comparisons, quality ratings and even sends a personalized alert to remind users of preventive screenings, how to manage their medications or where to find nearby providers that offer the best value. They’ve also recently launched Healthcare University, an online training program that uses videos, games and quizzes to teach employees about their health benefits. The stats on their <a title="Change Healthcare" href="http://www.changehealthcare.com/" target="_blank">homepage</a> will convince you that education and tools are important to promote consumerism.

<strong>Healthcare Blue Book</strong>: This service, launched in 2007 is a price transparency tool that operates similar to Kelly Blue Book in that it not only provides a range of available prices, but also estimates the “fair price” for a given procedure or medication. You can <a title="Healthcare Blue Book" href="https://www.healthcarebluebook.com/" target="_blank">try it out for free</a> by selecting a service and then entering your ZIP code. A premium version is available only through an employer or health plan.

<strong>Wiser Health</strong>: The company’s founder calls Wiser Health the “eHarmony” of healthcare decision-making tools.  It uses a similar algorithm to match users with the most appropriate care for their condition based on their cost limitations and personal preference. It’s also unique in that it allows people who have faced similar health issues to share their opinions about how satisfied they were with their treatments. You can access a <a title="Wiser Health" href="https://mywiserhealth.com/" target="_blank">short trial</a> period on their website.

This is just a short list of the services available to engage and educate your employees. I’ll be sure to update you with additional options in the future.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>As Costs Shift, Are Your Employees Prepared?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/as-costs-shift-are-your-employees-prepared/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Jun 2014 20:35:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=758</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

With rising health insurance premiums, deductibles and out-of-pocket expenses, many employees are not prepared to cover unexpected medical expenses. According to the 2014 <a title="2014 Aflac WorkForces Report" href="http://workforces.aflac.com/" target="_blank">Aflac WorkForces Report</a> that surveyed 5,209 employees in small, medium and large U.S. companies:
<ul>
	<li>49 percent have less than $1,000 to pay for unexpected out-of-pocket medical expenses.</li>
	<li>53 percent would borrow from their 401(k)s or use credit cards to cover expenses.</li>
	<li>66 percent say they wouldn’t be able to adjust to the large financial costs associated with a serious injury or illness.</li>
</ul>
This news is concerning, especially when you consider that The Kaiser Family Foundation recently <a title="Kaiser Foundation " href="http://kff.org/private-insurance/report/2013-employer-health-benefits" target="_blank">reported</a> that the number of workers covered by high deductible health plans has quadrupled, from 5 percent in 2007 to 20 percent in 2013. Some sources are saying high deductible plans grew to 25 percent in 2014. Clearly this is a trend that has gained momentum. And why not?

Companies can no longer foot the growing health care bill alone. Employees must get engaged to help control costs. And there’s no better way to get someone’s attention than by asking them to pony up to pay part of the cost. By the same token, you don’t want to throw your employees into the deep end without teaching them to swim.

So what can you do to educate and assist your employees as they handle more of the cost-sharing burden? I can sum it up in two words: ongoing education.

There are so many ways you can reach out to employees on a regular basis — a benefits website outside your company’s firewall, quarterly newsletters, tip sheets, social media, videos, posters, testimonials, webinars…the list goes on and on.  Use as many tools as possible, but more importantly, provide specific actions employees can take to control their costs. Be upfront about the impact on prescription costs and explain cost-saving techniques, such as using generics and home delivery. Stress the importance of accessing in-network providers. Provide links to price transparency tools available through your medical vendor. Raise awareness of no-cost preventive health services.

If there’s one constant I’ve seen in the benefits world over the past 21 years, it’s been change. And the most time-tested way to handle change is to communicate clearly, concisely and continuously.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Consumers Want to Be More Engaged in Health Care Decisions, but Hesitate to Ask About Costs</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/consumers-want-to-be-more-engaged-in-health-care-decisions-but-hesitate-to-ask-about-costs/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Jul 2014 16:37:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=763</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>By Elizabeth Borton</em>

Recent survey results show that 9 out of 10 consumers want to be in control of their medical decisions or at least share in the decision making with their doctors. However, they are not so willing to discuss the cost of care. While more than 80 percent say they would be comfortable discussing costs with their doctor, fewer than 50 percent have done so. The gap may be because only a third of those surveyed feel they’d be comfortable shopping for better health care prices.

The results come from the spring 2014 <em><a title="Altarum Institute Survey of Consumer Health Care Opinions" href="http://altarum.org/sites/default/files/uploaded-related-files/Spring_2014_Survey_of_Consumer_Health_Care_Opinions.pdf" target="_blank">Altarum Institute Survey of Consumer Health Care Opinions</a>, </em>which is conducted semi-annually to better understand consumer beliefs, practices and preferences regarding health care. The survey sampled 2,099 adults between the ages of 18 and 64 years old.

<strong>Key findings:</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>9 out of 10 consumers want to play a part in their medical decisions.</em></strong> Only 7 percent want their doctor to take the lead role.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Consumers will seek out information about their symptoms or medical condition, but not on costs or quality.</em></strong> Nearly 70 percent reported they look up their symptoms online rather than going to the doctor first. And 64 percent research their condition rather than relying solely on their doctor. However, only two in five looked for data on the cost or quality of care. When choosing a health care provider, 72 percent said they rely on word-of-mouth recommendations.</li>
	<li><strong><em>A persistent gap exists between attitudes and actions pertaining to health care costs. </em></strong>As stated above, 80 percent say they would feel comfortable discussing costs with their doctor; however, fewer than 50 percent have done so.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Although consumers want to be involved in health care decisions, many let the doctor take charge of the visit. </em></strong>About three in five consumers either ask a few questions or wait for the doctor to take the lead and tell them what to do. Only about 41 percent arrive with a list of questions to make sure they get the answers they need. However, 7 out of 10 consumers will accept a doctor’s recommendation despite having their own doubts.</li>
</ul>
Keep the results of this survey in mind as you develop your benefits communications. Provide links to decision making, price transparency and health care quality tools. Take advantage of free resources, such as the <a title="Choosing Wisely®" href="http://www.choosingwisely.org/doctor-patient-lists/" target="_blank"><em>Choosing Wisely® </em></a>initiative, which provides comprehensive lists of questions to ask providers for a variety of conditions. Educate your employees about the importance of engaging in all aspects of their health care, including quality and costs. After all, the emerging health care model depends on consumers making choices to meet their needs

The author of the study, Wendy Lynch, director of Altarum’s Center for Consumer Choice in Health Care, sums it up best: “We can’t assume that one size fits all for consumers – there remain wide variations in skills, attitudes and behaviors. Tailoring the right support to the right person will be critical for patient-centered care.”]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Testimonial + Humor = Engagement</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/testimonial-humor-engagement/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 24 Jul 2014 23:25:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=766</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Testimonials are a great benefits communications technique. There’s nothing like a good story, especially when it’s told by “people like me.” After all, research has repeatedly shown that people are most influenced by their peers. But have you ever tried combining a testimonial with humor?

A recent article entitled, <a title="High-deductible plans " href="http://hamptonroads.com/2014/07/highdeductible-plans-pit-health-against-wallet">“High-deductible plans pit health against wallet,”</a> caught our attention. The <em>Viginian-Pilot</em> writer, Elizabeth Simpson, takes a very down-to-earth, humorous perspective of her new health plan while providing some great tips. She speaks honestly about the eye-opening experience of receiving an almost $200 bill for a doctor’s visit as opposed to her previous $20 copay. As she put it, “It sent my mind reeling for better options.” She tries calling her plan administrator but gets frustrated with the phone tree, then tries to log on, but gets frustrated trying to set up her account. Finally she goes back to the email from HR announcing the new plan. She realizes the “euphemistically” entitled consumer driven plan expects employees to make financial decisions about their health care. Her response, “Wait, I don’t wanna drive! Let’s go back to the old days! Take the wheel, I beg of you!” However, after doing some research, Elizabeth starts to understand ways she can save money. She even considers taking advantage of the online doctor visits provided by her plan.

We really liked the article because it was so honest and entertaining but also informative. The next time you do testimonials, let your employees do the speaking. Don’t just use a couple of quotes and then fill in the rest of the text with your corporate perspective. Don’t be afraid to address the negatives and if possible, let your employees’ humor shine through. It will make the testimonials more engaging and spur readers to pass them along to others.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Common Communication Blunders (and how to avoid them)</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/common-communication-blunders-and-how-to-avoid-them-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 06 Oct 2014 19:45:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=768</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

<em>The following article I wrote was published in the September issue of Benefits magazine. If you are a member of the International Foundation of Employee Benefits (IFEBP), you should have received the magazine recently. With the IFEBP’s permission, I’m sharing the article with the rest of you below. Please feel free to pass it along.</em>

<a title=" Common Communication Blunders (and how to avoid them)" href="http://www.writetarget.com/Borton%20September%202014.pdf" target="_blank"> Common Communication Blunders (and how to avoid them)</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>ER Visits Expected to Spike During Flu Season Due to Ebola Scare</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/er-visits-expected-to-spike-during-flu-season-due-to-ebola-scare/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Oct 2014 20:59:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=773</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ebola cases in the United States have set off a media frenzy. It’s on the front page of every news website and at the top of every newscast. As hospitals across the country are scrambling to train staffs to treat patients safely, there’s a secondary impact they’re expecting — a spike in ER visits from those with the common flu.

The initial signs of infection are similar, so who can blame the public for being scared and wanting to take precautions? Especially when the Urgent Care Association <a title="Clinics check for ebola" href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/clinics-best-place-check-ebola-26315265" target="_blank">is requesting patients who suspect they have Ebola to go to the ER</a>, rather than one of their clinics.

<strong>How can you avoid a spike in your ER claims?</strong>

<strong>Communicate:</strong> Get in front of the issue now. Let employees know that Ebola only spreads when someone is sick. If they haven’t been exposed, then they probably have the common flu. This <a title="West Africa outbreaks" href="http://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/pdf/west-africa-outbreak-infographic.pdf" target="_blank">infographic</a> from the Center of Disease Control (CDC) illustrates the facts clearly and simply. If you have employees who travel to Africa, you may also want to review your policies and procedures. Check out the recent article from <strong>Employee Benefit News</strong> entitled  <a title="Easing ebola fears" href="http://ebn.benefitnews.com/news/ebn_co_benefits_communication/easing-ebola-fears-in-the-workplace-2744425-1.html" target="_blank">“Ebola Fears in the Workplace.”</a>

<strong>Educate</strong>: Provide tips on prevention and treatment through the flu season (October – March). The CDC offers a library of information and <a title="Free tools" href="http://www.cdc.gov/flu/" target="_blank">free communication tools</a>. If you have a wellness vendor, they should be able to offer materials to use as well.

<strong>Vaccinate</strong>: Encourage employees to get the flu vaccine. Emphasize that it is free of charge through your medical plan. Offer onsite vaccine clinics or promote the convenience of local providers.

The CDC estimates employers lose nearly $6.2 billion a year due to seasonal influenza. Factor in the Ebola scare and you can only imagine this year’s impact. Plan now to minimize the cost to your organization.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Why You Shouldn’t Rely On Supervisors to Communicate</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/why-you-shouldnt-rely-on-supervisors-to-communicate/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Nov 2014 20:20:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=783</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>By Elizabeth Borton</em></strong>

As I’ve been conducting year-end reviews with clients, I’ve heard a common concern, “How do I use my resources to reach and motivate “hard to reach” employee segments?” The answer depends on a variety of circumstances, however, an article I recently read shows why using local supervisors as your main communication channel may not be the solution.

The article is an update to research originally conducted by Angela Simickas in 1992, entitled “Supervisors are <span style="text-decoration:underline;">still</span> not the preferred communicators!” She found that the communications industry had relied on audits that were flawed.

In most audits, employees are provided a list of communication channels including print, electronic, audiovisual and in-person meetings and then asked to answer the following two questions:
<ol>
	<li>Which of these sources is <em>currently</em> your primary source for important company information?</li>
	<li>Which of these sources is your <em>preferred</em> primary source for important company information?</li>
</ol>
She writes, “The answer to the first question is almost always ‘rumors from other employees.’ The answer to the second is usually ‘my supervisor.’ It looks reasonable. It seems to make sense. There are statistically significant numbers to back it up. But it is all based on an illogical premise that becomes apparent if you change the subject from communications to consumer goods.” For example, in Simickas’ case, her <em>current</em> most frequent shopping venue was the grocery store. But her preferred primary shopping venue would be Cartier. So does that mean Cartier should start stocking groceries? Obviously not.

Simickas explains that the two questions are valid, but should be asked individually <em>by subject.</em> For example, electronic and print channels will often be the preferred source for detailed or highly graphic information. They also work for those who want to “see it in print” before they believe the company means it. Upper management tends to be the preferred source for high level strategic messages because employees don’t believe their supervisor would really know the answers. However, supervisors are the preferred source when it comes to interpreting company-wide issues at a local and “my job” level.

<strong>When you audit current and preferred information sources by subject:</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>You will be able to justify the investment you make </strong>in resource-intensive channels such as your website and newsletter, since they will be the current and preferred sources on many subjects.</li>
	<li><strong>You will be able to reduce the demand on supervisors and upper management. </strong>Simickas explains, “Your audit should result in a short, manageable list of topics that employees will want to hear about from their supervisors and a similarly short, but topically different, list of items to be presented by senior management in town halls or forums.” In this way, you can use your management team more strategically.</li>
	<li><strong>You will be able to identify the best combination of media to reach specific audiences about specific subjects.</strong></li>
</ul>
Her <a href="http://www.sinicom.com/Sub%20Pages/pubs/articles/article60.pdf" target="_blank">full article</a> includes results from dozens of audits as well as a great blueprint for conducting your next audit. It’s well worth the read. Follow her guidelines to conduct a viable audit that helps you to determine the best way to reach and motivate your “hard to reach” employees.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Health Care Terms Made Simple</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/health-care-terms-made-simple/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Nov 2014 20:27:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=787</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the challenges of benefits communications is keeping it simple. Terms like premiums, deductibles and provider networks, may seem obvious to you since you work in the business but are gobbledegook to your employees and their family members.

A recent survey released by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation found that four in ten uninsured did not know basic health insurance terms. And even fewer understood how to calculate cost-sharing amounts for services such as a hospital stay or an out-of-network lab test.

In response, the Kaiser Family Foundation released the third in a series of cartoon videos, designed to educate both the uninsured and insured. The newest video is entitled <a title="Health Insurance" href="http://kff.org/health-reform/video/health-insurance-explained-youtoons/" target="_blank">“<span style="text-decoration:underline;">Health Insurance Explained – The YouToons Have it Covered.</span>”</a> The video’s lighthearted approach makes it easy to understand insurance terms and concepts, such as coinsurance, copays and networks. It even explains how different insurance plans work when accessing medical care or prescriptions.

Take a few moments to watch the video. It’s a good example of simplifying the complex. Additional health insurance educational materials, including an online literacy test, are available for free on the <a title="Kaiser Family" href="http://kff.org/understanding-health-insurance/" target="_blank">Kaiser Family Foundation website</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Our Jimmy Fallon Thank You Notes</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/our-jimmy-fallon-thank-you-notes/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Nov 2014 22:05:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=794</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/11/jimmy-fallon-thank-you-image-1.jpg"><img class="alignleft wp-image-795" style="border:2px solid #ffffff;" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/11/jimmy-fallon-thank-you-image-1.jpg" alt="jimmy fallon thank you image 1" width="167" height="133" /></a>

<strong><em>In honor of Thanksgiving, we thought we’d share a couple thank you cards (ala Jimmy Fallon style) that we’d send if we could. Cue the music…</em></strong>

&nbsp;

Dear U.S. Government,
Thank you…not only for the Affordable Care Act but <span style="text-decoration:underline;">all</span> the HR-related legislation you’ve passed over the years…and then changed and changed and changed. Your non-stop efforts have kept us in business for over 21 years.
<p style="text-align:right;">– The Write On Target team</p>
Dear Biometric Screenings,
Thank you…for scheduling company screenings for weight and blood sugar in January. It’s a brilliant idea, since no one <span style="text-decoration:underline;">ever</span> over indulges during the holidays. Your sense of timing inspires us.
<p style="text-align:right;">– The Write On Target team</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tis the Season…for Checklists!</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/tis-the-seasonfor-checklists/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Dec 2014 21:18:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=806</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/santa-checking-list-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-807" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/santa-checking-list-1.jpg" alt="santa checking list 1" width="257" height="154" /></a>

As the holidays approach, we all have lists to check. Gifts to buy. Guests to invite. Food to prepare. Heck, even Santa is checking his naughty or nice list.

You may not think one more list is necessary, but consider your employees. They have a whole host of “to do’s” to complete in the next couple months. Why not make it easy on them by preparing a simple end-of-year checklist to follow?

<strong>Ideas for an employee end-of-year checklist
</strong><strong><em>Before end of year</em></strong><strong>
</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Make sure your home address is correct in the self-service system</li>
	<li>Consent to electronic delivery of your W2</li>
	<li>Use up your 2014 FSA dollars</li>
	<li>Complete your wellness activities to earn rewards</li>
	<li>Watch for new ID cards</li>
	<li>If changing prescription vendors: get refills done now, download the formulary for the new plan to give to your doctor</li>
</ul>
<strong><em>Starting in January</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li>If changing medical vendors: check to ensure your doctor is in the new network, show your new ID to providers to ensure your claims are processed correctly</li>
	<li>Check your first pay stub to make sure withholding amounts are correct</li>
	<li>If applicable, check to make sure your HSA contribution was made</li>
	<li>Schedule a performance review meeting with your manager</li>
	<li>Review your 401(k) contributions</li>
	<li>Review how to download or request duplicate W2s</li>
</ul>
The list above is just a few ideas to get you started. Consider the 2015 changes for your organization, then create an easy-to-follow checklist for your employees. It’s a small gift your employees will appreciate. Plus, it just might earn you a spot on Santa’s “nice” list!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Monday Morning Quarterback</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/monday-morning-quarterback/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 16 Dec 2014 21:36:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=812</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/monday-morning-quarterback-logo.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-813" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/monday-morning-quarterback-logo.jpg?w=300" alt="monday morning quarterback logo" width="300" height="100" /></a>

We hosted a webinar last week for the Health Action Council entitled “Monday Morning Quarterback — How to Analyze your 2015 Annual Enrollment and Prepare for Next Year.”

We’re not going to sum up an hour long webinar in this blog, especially since you’re probably busy finishing up your to-dos for the end of the year. But you might want to take a moment to do a little Monday morning quarterbacking of your communications over the past few months.

What worked well? What didn’t? Did you forget any key audiences and then have to rush to create something for them? Did you have any “emergencies” that ended up being an over-reaction from a small group of employees? How did your audiences embrace electronic communications and tools? Could you promote some of the tools throughout the year?

The benefit of doing the Monday morning quarterback exercise is that it will help you to plan for next year’s open enrollment. What’s more, you can apply the lessons learned in your HR communications game plan for 2015. After all, what worked (or didn’t) during enrollment will probably also apply to your wellness, 401(k), talent management and compensation campaigns in the coming year.

So during your holiday break, kick back and enjoy a few games. But keep a score pad nearby to jot down ideas as they come to you. Taking the offense, by learning from your past experience and planning ahead, will make you an MVP on the HR department team!

<em>Note: If you’re interested in the presentation (either by webinar or in person), contact Elizabeth Borton at </em><a href="mailto:eborton@writetarget.com"><em>eborton@writetarget.com</em></a><em>. It is pre-approved for HRCI certification. Details are at </em><a href="http://www.writetarget.com/where_were_at.html"><em>http://www.writetarget.com/where_were_at.html</em></a><em>. </em>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>publicize_twitter_url</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>How Social Savvy Is Your HR Department</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/how-social-savvy-is-your-hr-department/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Jan 2015 17:27:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=849</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>How Social Savvy Is Your HR Department?</strong>

This week, Forbes posted an article entitled “<a title="2015: Social HR Becomes A Reality" href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeannemeister/2015/01/05/2015-social-hr-becomes-a-reality/5/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">2015: Social HR Becomes A Reality</span></a>.”  The author, Jeanne Meister, says that “2015 will see the advent of the consumerization of HR,” where employees expect the same online user experience with HR as they do when they “reserve a taxi on Uber or pay their bills on the Bank of America mobile app.” And the expectation isn’t just among the younger generation. A recent MIT Sloan research report showed 57% of workers age 22 to 52 consider “social business sophistication” to be an important factor when choosing an employer. A Facebook Demographics report showed the fastest growing demographic on both YouTube and Google + is 45-54 years old. As Meister notes, “research suggests that we are no longer divided into a world of either digital immigrants or digital natives: Instead, we are now all digital citizens.”

The article cites several ways HR can become more social, from the very tech savvy to the simple. Two of the most interesting are the development of HR apps and expanding the use of gamification beyond wellness to learning.

According to Gartner, a leading information technology research and advisory company, <a title="Corporate App Store" href="http://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/2334015">25% of all enterprises will have their own Corporate App Store</a> by 2017. In fact, many companies are developing apps for HR and learning. Cognizant Technology Solutions has developed over 50 apps to drive greater interest in continuous learning. Combine that type of technology with the science of gamification and you’ve got yourself a winning training and engagement strategy. NTT Data developed an Ignite Leadership game that quickly expanded from 70 leaders to over 700. The game was developed to train leaders in five key skills: negotiation, communication, time management, change management and problem solving. Incentives were linked to the games, offering 6 hours of training credit towards the mandatory 20 hours for completion of the games. Plus sites were recognized for team participation in the games.

As Meister says, “it’s important to remember gamification in the workplace is not just about using badges, mission and leaderboards. If designed properly, it is a form of engagement which identifies a learning objective and target audience, then determines what motivates them. From there, gamification can change the way employees work, communicate and innovate with peers and customers.”

Learn more by reading Meister’s column “<a title="Gamification for Leadership Development" href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeannemeister/2013/09/30/gamification-in-leadership-development-how-companies-use-gaming-to-build-their-leader-pipeline/"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Gamification for Leadership Development</span></a>.”]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Educate Employees About The Pros and Cons of Raiding Their 401(k)</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/educate-employees-about-the-pros-and-cons-of-raiding-their-401k/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Feb 2015 09:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=856</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[According to a recent <a title="Gallup" href="http://www.gallup.com/poll/180311/one-five-investors-tapped-401-prematurely.aspx?utm_source=tagrss&amp;utm_medium=rss&amp;utm_campaign=syndication&amp;utm_reader=feedly" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Gallup</span></a> poll, 89 percent of Americans are participating in a 401(k) plan if it is offered by their employer. Among those participating, 96 percent say they are actively contributing to their plan. Plus, according to investment management specialists at Vanguard, by the end of 2013, the average 401(k) account had doubled in size from 2008 levels to more than $100,000.

That’s all great news. It shows that Americans realize they need to take an active role in saving for their retirement.

But here’s the catch. When American workers come upon hard times, they tend to tap their 401(k) plans. In fact, the Gallup data shows that 16 percent have taken out loans against their accounts, 9 percent have made early withdrawals and 5 percent have done both.

A  loan is preferable to a 401(k)withdrawal, which is subject to both income tax and a 10 percent penalty if the employee is age 59-1/2. However, based on those stats, it’s important to educate your employees about the pros and cons of taking a loan against their 401(k). The following may help you to craft an article for your next newsletter.

<strong><em>Note: Be sure to update the specific loan rules below, based on your company’s
plan design.</em></strong>

<strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Taking a loan against a 401(k)</span></strong>

<strong>Pros:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>401(k) rules permit loans up to 50 percent of your total savings, up to a limit of $50,000.</li>
	<li>The interest rate is generally prime plus a percentage point or two (so about
5 percent today) which is lower than the average interest charged on a credit card advance (now averaging 13 percent) or a payday loan (36 percent and up).</li>
</ul>
<strong>Cons:</strong>
<ul>
	<li>You may be required to pay a loan origination fee, administrative, maintenance, or other fees — all of which add to the loan's cost and further drain your account.</li>
	<li>You need to make regular loan repayments — at least quarterly — until the loan is repaid.</li>
	<li>The loan repayments are made in after-tax dollars. This means you’re missing out on tax advantages by replacing tax-free savings with after-tax dollars.</li>
	<li>You need to repay the entire loan within five years or the outstanding balance is considered a “withdrawal.” You will then need to pay applicable taxes and penalties on the “withdrawal” amount.</li>
</ul>
For more information, check out <a title="Daily Finance" href="http://www.dailyfinance.com/2015/02/04/good-news-bad-news-401k/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">this article</span></a> and additional links on the Daily Finance website.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Common Communication Blunders (and how to avoid them)</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/common-communication-blunders-and-how-to-avoid-them/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Sep 2014 12:21:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[bbotos]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://dev.writetarget.com/?p=2741</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;">As seen in Benefit News: <a href="http://www.writetarget.com/Borton%20September%202014.pdf">Read Here</a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2741</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-09-01 12:21:56</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-09-01 12:21:56</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>common-communication-blunders-and-how-to-avoid-them</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>5 Tips for Knock-Their-Socks-Off Total Rewards Statements</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/5-tips-for-knock-their-socks-off-total-rewards-statements/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Jan 2015 03:43:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=824</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em><a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/01/sock-photos-for-verderber.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-826 alignleft" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/01/sock-photos-for-verderber.jpg?w=300" alt="sock photos for Verderber" width="223" height="243" /></a></em>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<em>Happy New Year! Since many of you are looking at doing total rewards statements in the next couple months, we thought you might enjoy this guest blog from Rita Verderber. Enjoy!</em>

<strong>5 Tips for Knock-Their-Socks-Off Total Rewards Statements
</strong>While knocking off socks is a lofty goal, a well-designed total rewards statement can have that level of positive impact. When an employee with a $50,000 base wage sees their actual total compensation (pay + benefits) is closer to $71,000, it can be a socks-knocking experience.<strong>
</strong>

The power of a total rewards statement comes from the personal and detailed picture it gives employees of the full value of their work. In addition to pay and benefits, total rewards statements can also convey the value of non-monetary rewards such as work-life balance, opportunities for growth, and a great company culture.

<strong>A Brilliant Total Rewards Statement has Pizzazz
</strong>If your total rewards statements are cold, boring, or greeted with skepticism, these five tips can help give them some zing:

<strong>1. Put Employees First
</strong>Think not what a total rewards statement can do for your company . . . but what it can do for individual employees. Put your company’s strategic goals on the shelf for the moment, and get a clear vision of how your statements can help employees. When you put employees first, your statements will ultimately also yield the greatest return for your company.<strong>
</strong>

<strong>2. Deliver Statements with Fanfare
</strong>Print, online, PDF, microsites—there are many options for formatting and delivering your statements. One consideration is paramount: how many of your employees will actually <em>see</em> their statement? How many spouses will see it?<strong>
</strong>

Your statements may be masterpieces of design and marvels of technology, but if employees don’t rip open the envelope or login to view them, they’re utterly worthless.

Let employees know their statements are coming. Give managers advance notice, and reinforce the message—a job with your company is much more than just a paycheck! Consider tying the release of the statements to a special event. Include employee testimonials to heighten interest. If you deliver online statements, think about how you can encourage employees to view their statements and share them with spouses.

<strong>3. Make it Personal
</strong>Tell employees a story that’s all about them. The more personalized a total rewards statement, the more powerful its message will be. Put the value of total compensation front and center. Provide helpful information about benefits coverage and retirement savings. Use variable text to eliminate generalities so that every piece of information is relevant to the recipient.<strong>
</strong>

In addition, tell your company’s story. Brand statements so they are unmistakably your own. Communicate what makes your company a great place to work, and why employees should choose to stay. Keeping quiet and letting employees draw their own conclusions is a disservice to both the company and employees.

<strong>4. Happiness is a Total Rewards Statement
</strong>By their very nature, total rewards statements send an upbeat message that the company values employees, respects them, and is focused on rewarding and retaining them. Leave the somber tone and legal language to the SPDs. Use color and graphics to create a friendly tone. Show pride in your company, your employees, and the work you do together to serve customers.<strong>
</strong>

<strong>5. Don’t Get Cold Feet
</strong>Total rewards programs represent substantial investments in employees’ well-being. They are key factors for job satisfaction and retention. In a survey by WorldatWork, HR professionals judged total rewards statements to be the single most effective method for communicating the employee value proposition. So make a bold statement! Tell your company’s total rewards story with pride, and socks-knocking pizzazz.<strong>
</strong>

<em>Rita Verderber is founder and President of Insight Benefit Communications Inc. Her company has been creating sock-knockin' total rewards statements for over 19 years. You can reach her at </em><a href="mailto:rita@insightben.com"><em>rita@insightben.com</em></a><em>.</em>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Using Google Analytics to Promote Your Wellness Program</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/using-google-analytics-to-promote-your-wellness-program/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Feb 2015 17:32:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=852</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The folks over at Airbo.com launched a new blog this past week with an eye-catching title, “<a href="http://blog.airbo.com/worst-time-to-launch-a-wellness-program/?utm_source=Engagement+Hub+List+January+2015&amp;utm_campaign=ee324cf2d4-Monthly_Blog_Post_Digest1_22_2015&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_term=0_1ee574556a-ee324cf2d4-356994033" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration:underline;">When is the worst time to launch a wellness campaign?</span></a>” They used Google Analytics to show that even though most wellness campaigns are introduced in the fall during open enrollment, it’s about the worst timing possible. That’s because people are much more focused on turkey thighs, rather than their own, during what Airbo calls the “Wellness Dead Zone” (October to December). Promoting healthy activities going into the holidays is similar to the backlash Weight Watchers is getting this morning for their anti-drug like spot during the food-frenzied Super Bowl.  As they say, timing is everything.

The conundrum is that most companies integrate their medical plans and wellness programs, so they both need to be discussed during open enrollment. However, that doesn’t preclude you from taking advantage of the spike in interest occurring now.  According to Google Analytics cited in the article, the search patterns for words like “fitness,” “diet,” and “healthy” are “freakishly consistent” at this time of year, then gradually decrease until the holidays roll around again. That means you should focus on promoting the healthy activities available through your wellness program now, then continue throughout the year. But keep in mind, the analytics also showed that few people search for the word “wellness” so be sure to use terms like “fitness,” “diet,” and “healthy” in your text, especially on your website.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Improve New Employee Onboarding with Technology</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/improve-new-employee-onboarding-with-technology/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2015 20:09:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=864</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Engaging new employees, and building on that day-one enthusiasm, is one of the main goals of a successful onboarding program. It’s a challenge but technology can help you connect with new hires immediately and keep them engaged long after their first day of work.

Email is one of the easiest and quickest ways to add technology to your onboarding program. Before your new employees even start, send out a “welcome to the team” email that includes a message from the CEO and key executives. This is a great way to introduce employees to the leadership team. And by including links to any company videos, you provide new employees with an overview of company culture before day one.

Create a new hire portal on your web site where employees can access all administrative tasks, update employment information, take any required new hire training, upload a company photo and anything else that they can get done before the first day of work. Make use of electronic signature and verification tools for completing benefits paperwork. By pre-boarding most of these tasks, employees will  feel immediately productive from day one.

If your company has an online social network, you should also create a special section for new hires.  Encourage new hires to join online conversations, ask questions and participate in company polls and surveys. Online corporate communities can also be used long after the first day of employment to help new hires get to know each other, build their own internal community or network, and teach each other the ropes as they learn company processes and procedures. Your company’s social network is a great tool to engage new hires and connect them to other people throughout the company.

Find out more about how technology can improve your new employee onboarding program. Check out <a title="Workforce" href="http://www.workforce.com/articles/19977-onboarding-tips-and-best-practices-for-bringing-new-workers-on-board"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">this article</span></a> and additional links on the Workforce website.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why Emails Don’t Work</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/why-emails-dont-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 14:27:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=868</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/50570513_1369041765.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-874" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/50570513_1369041765.jpg?w=300" alt="50570513_1369041765" width="300" height="192" /></a>

An article at Management-Issues.com got my attention this past week. It was titled, “<a title="Business Writing" href="http://www.management-issues.com/connected/7020/why-business-writing-doesnt-communicate/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Why business writing doesn’t communicate</span></a>.” It was an interview with Phil Simon the writer of seven management books, including “<a title="Message Not Received" href="http://www.amazon.com/Message-Not-Received-Business-Communication-ebook/dp/B00TTY9UKO/?tag=viglink25411-20"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Message Not Received:</span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> Why Business Communication Is Broken and How to Fix It</span></a>” which was recently released. I’ve downloaded the book and am anxious to read it.

Simon points out what we all know…companies have become too dependent on email as their primary form of communication. Yes, it’s inexpensive. Yes, it’s timely. But when employees are inundated with hundreds, if not thousands of emails a day, you have to ask yourself, “Is it effective?”

Instead of a simple one minute phone call or stopping by a fellow employee’s cubicle, folks feel the urge to put their thoughts in writing and copy everyone on the team. But are they really communicating? Simon’s book points out some real-world scenarios, “Think about how many misunderstandings could have been averted at your organization if two colleagues had simply engaged in a five-minute in-person conversation or videoconference over Skype. Ask yourself how many technical problems could have been solved with a quick phone call and a simple screen-sharing session. Have you ever missed a truly critical e-mail because it was hidden in your never-ending inbox? Have you even been unable to do your jobs because key documents languished in someone's inbox or on someone's hard drive?”

Another common mistake in email is the use of jargon or corporate buzzwords, both of which turn people off. (C’mon…how many of you have ever played <a title="Buzzword Bingo" href="http://www.businessbuzzwordbingo.com"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">business buzzword bingo</span></a> during a conference call?) Keep in mind, ‘communicate’ means “to make common.” I don’t care how sophisticated your audience may be, when it comes to HR and benefits, the simpler you keep your text, the better.

I’m looking forward to reading Simon’s book to get a better understanding of alternative communication strategies. In the meantime, the next time I get ready to send an email, I’m going to ask myself —Is it clear? Is it concise? Is it necessary? It might be better to just pick up my phone or drop by for a visit.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Pssst: Your most valuable communication tool is in the next cubicle</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/pssst-your-most-valuable-communication-tool-is-in-the-next-cubicle/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Mar 2015 15:10:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[writetarget]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetargetblog.com/?p=877</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Companies spend a lot of money marketing their HR “brand” through a variety
of channels. But did you realize your most valuable communications tool is in the
next cubicle?

<a href="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/office-cubicle-moresheth-flickr1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-880" src="https://writetarget.files.wordpress.com/2015/03/office-cubicle-moresheth-flickr1.jpg?w=300" alt="office-cubicle-moresheth-flickr" width="300" height="142" /></a>

That’s right. Your employees are the most influential and powerful group to help you recruit great talent, communicate the value of your benefits and get others involved in your wellness programs, to name just a few HR initiatives. Whether in person or through their social media networks, they are more influential than any combination of traditional communications.

An <a title="Undercover Recruiter" href="http://theundercoverrecruiter.com/social-employees-marketing/" target="_blank"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">infographic</span></a> posted by Undercover Recruiter and created by <a href="https://gaggleamp.com/" target="_blank">GaggleAmp</a> (a social media amplification service), illustrates just how powerful your employees can be.

<strong>Did you know?</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Just one person who shares your message results in far more click-through activity than if your company were to add 100 followers.</li>
	<li>The collective reach of your employee’s posts far surpasses the reach of your company. Just 60 employees can increase your company’s reach by <strong>1,000%</strong>.</li>
	<li>Employee posts have farther <strong>reach</strong> than company posts, due to the amount of filtering on company posts by social platforms.</li>
	<li>On average, <strong>73.8%</strong> of the potential engagement on a social media post happens in the first hour.</li>
	<li>When your employees are leveraged to share posts, the engagement lifespan is extended by <strong>4,200%</strong> thanks to your employees sharing over time.</li>
</ul>
Arm your employees to be your HR brand ambassadors.  Encourage them to share interesting stories about their life at your company. Ask them to post links to positions in your company. Their involvement will humanize your company and build trust with prospective recruits. Create a Facebook page for your wellness program and promote interactive participation among employees and their family members. The support and friendly competition that results will build awareness and increase engagement in your programs.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What do employees value more than benefits?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/what-do-employees-value-more-than-benefits/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Apr 2015 18:27:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Dane]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetarget.com/?p=3196</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Consistent communications.

In a survey of 1,000 employees, <a href="http://www.15five.com/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">15Five</span></a> found that 81% of employees would rather join a company that values open communication than one that offers great health plans, free food and gym memberships. Specifically, having their manager check in with them for 15 minutes each week is more important to employees than a top benefits package. (Their <a href="http://tech.co/infographic-communication-more-valuable-than-benefits-2015-04"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">infographic</span></a> provides more stats from the survey.)

Since 15Five sells a software platform for internal communications, their survey is a bit self-serving, but an article in the<a href="https://hbr.org/2015/04/what-great-managers-do-to-engage-employees"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> Harvard Business Review </span></a>shows their findings are backed up by Gallop’s research. A survey of over 7,000 U.S. adults found that “consistent communication – whether it occurs in person, over the phone or electronically - is connected to higher engagement.” In fact, “employees whose managers hold regular meetings with them are almost three times as likely to be engaged.” Great managers connect with their employees on a regular, sometimes daily basis. In addition to reviewing responsibilities and progress on projects, they also talk to them about what happens in their lives outside of work.

You should apply this same principle to your HR communications. Don’t just communicate a few times a year. Communicate with employees on a regular basis. And don’t make it a one-way conversation. Utilize tools that allow employees to ask questions and connect with each other. This <a href="http://www.wmfc.org/uploads/GenerationalDifferencesChart.pdf">chart</a> will help you to understand the various ways you can connect and engage with employees across your multi-generational workforce. The trick is to be authentic, consistent and interactive.

As Oprah often said, “Everyone just wants to be heard.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Wellness: go beyond metrics and challenges to achieve success</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/wellness-go-beyond-metrics-and-challenges-to-achieve-success/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Apr 2015 19:33:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Dane]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetarget.com/?p=3224</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Fran Melmed, a thought leader in the wellness industry, had an interesting <u><a href="http://www.freerangecomm.com/2015/04/gender-parity-freedom-and-responsibility-wonder-at-life-rule-at-virgin-disruptors-event/?utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Free-rangeCommunication+%28free-range+communication%29">blog</a></u> about the <u><a href="https://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/want-to-be-a-disruptor-keep-an-open-mind">Virgin Disruptors</a></u> event this week. Over the three-hour discussion, she didn’t hear any talk of “how to engage employees in challenges, incent them to complete a health risk assessment or measure their biometrics.” Sure, the speakers’ organizations, including host Richard Branson and panelists from Facebook, Zappos, The Huffington Post and Yahoo, do those things. But the takeaway was that true well-being is promoted by giving employees “the freedom and responsibility to do amazing things, to bring one’s whole self to work and wonder at life, to have and tend to family, to understand that the customer experience and the employee experience align and the expectation that pay is not a gender issue.”

Wow.

In case you think that’s “pie in the sky” talk and not practical, consider the article in <u>US News &amp; World Report,</u> <a href="http://money.usnews.com/money/blogs/outside-voices-careers/2015/04/13/8-employee-wellness-ideas-that-would-actually-work">“<u>8 Employee Wellness Ideas That Would Actually Work”</u></a>. The article suggests that instead of putting the burden on employees to change their lifestyle (which they resent and resist), look at ways your organization can promote wellness, including:
<ol>
	<li>Provide easy access to healthy meals and snacks.</li>
	<li>Make it easier for people to exercise.</li>
	<li>Stop the weight-loss competitions.</li>
	<li>Offer great health insurance.</li>
	<li>Discourage people from coming to work sick.</li>
	<li>Stop requiring doctors’ notes for sick employees.</li>
	<li>Provide reasonable amounts of paid sick time.</li>
	<li>Encourage people to actually use their vacation time.</li>
</ol>
Considering the EEOC’s new proposed rules around wellness programs (summarized <u><a href="http://www.theemployerhandbook.com/2015/04/revealed-the-eeocs-new-proposed-wellness-program-rules.html">here</a></u>), it might be time to take a step back and consider what your organization can do to promote wellness, rather than forcing lifestyle changes on employees. By moving beyond metrics and challenges, you may create a wellness program that truly succeeds.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
		<title>Employees not engaged in annual enrollment?</title>
		<link>http://writetarget.com/employees-not-engaged-in-annual-enrollment/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 May 2015 18:03:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JulieWOT]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://writetarget.com/?p=3320</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Results from <a href="https://benefittrends.metlife.com/">MetLife’s 13<sup>th</sup> Annual Employee Benefit Trends Study</a> confirm what most HR professionals already know: employees simply aren’t engaged in the annual enrollment process. But this isn’t due to a lack of interest. It’s from lack of understanding because their benefits communications aren’t easy to understand. Employee benefits are too complex to navigate and too time-consuming to figure out without some guidance.

While employees are playing a larger role in making benefits decisions, they aren’t always confident that they’re making the <em>right </em>decisions. And they feel like they just don’t understand the options.

Key findings from the study show that:
<ul>
	<li><strong><em>61% of employees make their annual enrollment selections as soon as they are notified.</em></strong> 14% wait until the last minute. The reason for this is because employees aren’t educated about company benefits.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Overall, 37% of employees say they need more help in understanding how their benefits work and which benefits meet their needs.</em></strong> This percentage increases to 54% for younger workers.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Employees who find their benefits communications effective are twice as likely to be loyal to their company. </em></strong>74% said their benefits communications helped them make smart choices.</li>
</ul>
As you develop your benefits communications, keep the results of this study in mind. Provide your employees with links to decision making, price transparency and health care quality tools. Educate your employees about the importance of engaging in all aspects of their benefits so they choose options that best meet their needs. And provide benefits information throughout the year with personalized messaging that targets each generation in the workforce.]]></content:encoded>
